Play details
The Dutch courtezan. Genre: Tragedy. Date first published: 1605. Date first performed: 1603-1605.

editorialDecl.p: Prose and verse allocated as in New Mermaids ed., ed. David Crane, 1997

Officer
Fabule argumentum

langUsage.p: The languages (other than English) which occur in the text are identified by idREF which point to the following.

div1.stage: AS IT WAS PLAYD IN THE Blacke Friars, by the Children of her Maiesties Reuels

sp.speaker: Prologue
sp.l: Slight hasty labours in this easy Play,
Present not what you would, but what we may:
For this vouchsafe to know the only end
Of our now study is, not to offend.
Yet think not, but like others rail we could,
(Best art Presents, not what it can, but should)
And if our pen in this seem over slight,
We strive not to instruct, but to delight,
As for some few, we know of purpose here
to tax, and scout: know firm art cannot fear
Vain rage: only the highest grace we pray
Is, you will not tax, until you judge our Play.
Think and then speak: it is rashness, and not wit
To speak what is in passion, and not judgment fit:
Sit then, with fair expectance, and survey
Nothing but passionate man in his slight play,
Who hath this only ill: to some deemed worst,
A modest diffidence, and self mistrust.

stage.p: The difference betwixt the loue of a Curtezan, & a wife, is the full scope of the Play, which intermixed with the deceits of a wittie Citie Iester, fils vp the Comedie.

div2.stage: Enter 3: Pages with lightes. Malligrubb, Freeuile, Malheureux, Tisefeu. amp; Caqueteur.

sp.speaker: Freeuile
sp.p: Nay comfort my good host Sharke, my good Mulligrubb.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Advance thy snout, do not suffer thy sorrowful nose to drop on thy spanish leather jerkin, most hardly honest Mulligrub.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: What, cogging Cocledemoy is run away with a nest of goblets, true, what then? they will be hammered out well enough, I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.p: Sure, some wise man would find them out presently.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Yes sure, if we could find out some wise man presently:

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: How was the plate lost? how did it vanish?

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: In most sincere prose thus: that man of much money, some wit, but less honesty, cogging Cocledemoy, comes this night late into mine hosts Mulligrubs Tavern here, calls for a room, the house being full, Cocledemoy consorted with his moveable chattel, his instrument of fornication, the bawd Mrs. Mary Faugh, are imparlarde next the street, good poultry was their food, blackbird, Lark, woodcock, and mine host here, comes in, cries God bless you, and departs: A blind Harper enters, craves audience, uncaseth, plays, the Drawer for female privateness sake is nodded out, who knowing that whosoever will hit the mark of profit, must like those that shoot in stone-bows wink with one eye, grows blind a the right side and departs.

sp.speaker: Caque.
sp.p: He shall answer for that winking with one eye at the last day.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Let him have day till then, and he will wink with both his eyes.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Cocledemoy perceiving none in the room but the blind Harper, (whose eyes heaven had shut up, from beholding wickedness,) unclasps a casement to the street very patiently, pockets up three bowls unnaturally, thrusts his wench forth the window, and himself most preposterously with his heels forward follows, the unseeing Harper plays on, bids the empty dishes and the treacherous candles much good do them. The Drawer returns, but out alas, not only the birds, but also the nest of goblets were flown away, Laments are raised.

sp.speaker: Tysep.
sp.p: Which did not pierce the heavens.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: The Drawers moan, mine host doth cry, the bowls are gone.

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.p: Hic finis Priami.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Nay, be not jaw fallen, my most sharking Mulligrub.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: It is your just affliction, remember the sins of the cellar, and repent, repent.

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.p: I am not jaw fallen, but I will hang the cony catching Cocledemoy, and there is an end of it.

sp.speaker: Caque.
sp.p: Is it a right stone, it shows well by candlelight.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: So do many things that are counterfeit, but I assure you this is a right Diamond.

sp.speaker: Caque.
sp.p: Might I borrow it of you, it will not a little grace my finger in visitation of my Mistress.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Why use it most sweet Caqueture, use it.

sp.speaker: Caque.
sp.p: Thanks good Sir, it is grown high night: Gentles, rest to you.

sp.speaker: Tysep.
sp.p: A torch, sound wench, soft sleep, and sanguine dreams to you both, on boy.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Let me bid you good rest.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Not so trust me, I must bring my friend home: I dare not give you up to your own company, I fear the warmth of wine and youth, will draw you to some Common house of lascivious entertainment.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Most necessary buildings Malheureus ever since my intention of Marriage, I do pray for their continuance.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Loved Sir, your reason?

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Marry lest my house should be made one: I would have married men love the Stews, as Englishmen loved the low Countries: wish war should be maintained there, lest it should come home to their own doors: what, suffer a man to have a hole to put his head in, though he go to the Pillory for it: Youth and Appetite are above the Club of Hercules.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: This lust is a most deadly sin sure.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Nay, it is a most lively sin sure.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Well I am sure, it is one of the head sins.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Nay, I am sure it is one of the middle sins.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Pity, it is grown a most daily vice.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: But a more nightly vice, I assure you.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Well, it is a sin.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Aye , or else few men would wish to go to Heaven: and not to disguise with my friend, I am now going the way of all flesh.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Not to a Courtesan.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: A courteous one.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: What to a Sinner?

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: A very Publican.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Dear my loved friend, let me be full with you,
Know Sir, the strongest argument that speaks
Against the souls eternity is lust,
That Wise man's folly, and the fools wisdom:
But to grow wild in loose lasciviousness,
Given up to heat, and sensual Appetite:
Nay to expose your health, and strength, and name,
Your precious time, and with that time the hope
Of due preferment advantageous means,
Of any worthy end to the stale use,
The common bosom of a money Creature,
One that sells human flesh: a Mangonist.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Alas good creatures, what would you have them do? would you have them get their living by the curse of man, the sweat of their brows? so they do, every man must follow his trade, and every woman her occupation: a poor decayed mechanical man's wife, her husband is laid up, may not she lawfully be laid down, when her husbands only rising, is by his wifes falling? a Captains wife wants means, her Commander lies in open field abroad, may not she lie in civil arms at home. A waiting Gentlewoman that had wont to take say to her Lady, miscarries, or so: the Court misfortune throws her down, may not the City courtesy take her up: do you know no Alderman would pity such a woman's case: why is charity grown a sin? or relieving the poor and impotent an offence? You will say beasts take no money for their fleshly entertainment: true, because they are beasts, therefore beastly, only men give to lose, because they are men, therefore manly: and indeed, wherein should they bestow their money better? In Land, the title may be cracked: In Houses, they maybe burnt: In apparel, it will wear: In wine, alas for pity our throat is but short: But employ your money upon women, and a thousand to nothing, some one of them will bestow that on you, which shall stick by you as long as you live; they are no ingrateful persons, they will give quite for quo: do ye protest, they will swear, do you rise, they will fall do you fall, they will rise, do you give them, the french Crown, they will give you the french --- O iustus iusta iustum. They sell their bodies: do not better persons sell their souls? nay, since all things have been sold, honour, justice, faith: nay, even God himself:
sp.l: Aye me, what base ignobleness is it,
To sell the pleasure of a wanton bed.
Why do men scrape, why heap to full heaps join,
But for his Mistress, who would care for coin,
For this I hold to be denied of no man,
All things are made for man, and man for woman, give me my fee!

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Of ill you merit well: my hearts good friend,
Leave yet at length, at length, for know this ever
It is no such sin to err, but to persevere.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p:
Beauty is woman's virtue, love the life's Music: and woman the daintiness or second course of heavens curious workmanship, since then beauty love and woman are good, how can
the love of woman's beauty be bad? and, Bonum quo communius eo melius, will it then go with me?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Whether?

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: To a house of salvation.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Salvation?

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Yes it will make thee repent. will it go to the family of love? I will show thee my creature: a pretty nimble eyed Dutch Tanakin; An honest soft hearted impropriation, a soft plump, round cheeked froe, that has beauty enough, for her virtue, virtue enough for a woman, and woman enough for any reasonable man in my knowledge: will it pass a long with me?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: What to a Brothel, to behold an impudent prostitution, fie on it I shall hate the whole sex to see her: the most odious spectacle the earth can present, is an immodest vulgar woman.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Good still: my brain shall keep is: you must go as you love me.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Well: I will go to make her loath the shame she is in.
The sight of vice augments the hate of sin.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: The sight of vice augments the hate of sin,
sp.p: very fine pardy.

sp.speaker: Cocle:
sp.p: Mary, Mary Faugh

sp.speaker: Mar:
sp.p: Hem.

sp.speaker: Cocle:
sp.p: Come my worshipful Rotten Rough bellied Bawd, ha my blue toothed Patrons of natural wickedness, give me the goblets.

sp.speaker: Mar:
sp.p: By yea, and by nay, master Cocledemoy I fear you will play the knave and restore them.

sp.speaker: Cocle:
sp.p: No by the Lord Aunt, Restitution is Catholic and thou knowest we love----

sp.speaker: Mar:
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: Cocle:
sp.p: Oracles are seized: Tempus preteritum, dost hear my worshipful glisterpipe, thou ungodly fire that burnt Dianas Temple, dost hear Bawd.

sp.speaker: Mar:
sp.p: In very good truthness you are the foulest mouthed profane railing Brother, call a woman the most ungodly names: I must confess we all eat of the forbidden fruit, and for mine own part though I am one of the family of love and as they say a bawd that covers the multitude of sins, yet I trust I am none of the wicked that eat fish a Fridays.

sp.speaker: Cocle:
sp.p: Hang toasts, I rail at thee my worshipful organ bellows that fills the pipes, my fine rattling phlegmy cough a the lunges and cold with a Pox, I rail at thee what my right precious panderess supportress of Barber Surgeons and inhauntres of lotium and diet drink: I rail at thee necessary damnation, I will make an oration, I, in praise of thy most courtly in fashion, and most pleasurable function, I.

sp.speaker: Mar:
sp.p: I prithee do, I love to hear myself praised, as well as any old Lady, I.

sp.speaker: Cocle:
sp.p: List then, a Bawd, first for her profession or vocation it is most worshipful of all the twelve Companies, for as that trade is most honourable that sells the best commodities, as the Draper is more worshipful than the pointmaker, the silkman more worshipful than the Draper, and the Goldsmith more honourable than both, Little Mary: so the Bawd above all, her shop has the best ware, for where these sell but cloth, satins, and jewels, she sells divine virtues as virginity, modesty and such rare Gems, and those not like a petty chapman, by retail, but like a great merchant by whole sale, wa, ha, ho, and who are her customers, not base corn cutters, or sow-gelders, but most rare wealthy Knights, and most rare bountiful Lords are her customers: Again, where as no trade or vocation profiteth, but by the loss and displeasure of another, as the Merchant thrives not but by the licentiousness of giddy, and unsettled youth: the Lawyer, but by the vexation of his client, the Physician, but by the maladies of his patient, only my smooth gummed Bawd lives by others pleasure, and only grows rich by others rising, O merciful gain, O righteous income. So much for her vocation, trade and life, as for their death, how can it be bad, since their wickedness is always before their eyes, and a deaths head most commonly on their middle finger. To conclude, it is most certain they must needs both live well, and die well, since most commonly they live in Clearken-well, and die in Bridewell. Dixi Mary.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Come along, yonder is the preface or exordium to my wench, the bawd: Fetch, fetch. What M. Cocledemoy, is your knaveship yet stirring, look to it, Mulligrub lies for you.

sp.speaker: Cocle:
sp.p: The more fool he, I can lie for myself, worshipful friend, hang toasts, I vanish. Ha my fine boy thou art a scholar, and hast read Tullies Offices, my fine knave, hang toasts.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: The Vintner will toast you if he catch you.

sp.speaker: Cocle:
sp.p: I will draw the Vintner to the stoop, and when he runs low tilt him, ha my fine knave, art going to thy recreation?

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Yes my capricious rascal.

sp.speaker: Cocle:
sp.p: Thou wilt look like a fool then by and by.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Look like a fool why?

sp.speaker: Cocle:
sp.p: Why according to the old saying, A beggar when he is lousing of himself looks like a Philosopher, a hard bound Philosopher, when he is on the stool, looks like a tyrant, and a wise man, when he is in his belly act, looks like a fool, God give your worship good rest, grace and mercy keep your Siring straight, and your Lotium unspilt.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: See, Sir this is she.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: This?

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: This.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: A Courtesan? Now cold blood defend me, what a proportion afflicts me?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: O mine aderliuer love, what shall me do to requite this your mush affection.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Marry salute my friend, clip his neck, and kiss him welcome.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: A mine art, Sir you been very welcome.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Kiss her man with a more familiar affection, so, come what entertainment, go to your Lute.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: And how dost approve my sometimes elected? she is none of your ramping Cannibals, that devour man's flesh, nor any of your curtian gulfs, that will never be satisfied, until the best thing a man has be thrown into them. I loved her with my heart, until my soul showed me the imperfection of my body, and placed my affection on a lawful love, my modest Beatrice, which if this short heels knew, there were no being for me with eyes before her face. But faith, dost thou not somewhat excuse my sometimes incontinency with her enforcive beauties. Speak.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: Ha, she is a whore, is she not?

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Whore? fie whore? you may call her a Courtesan, a Cockatrice, or (as that worthy spirit of an eternal happiness said ) a Suppository, but whore? fie: it is not in fashion to call things by their right names, is a great merchant, a cuckold, you must say, he is one of the livery, is a great Lord, a fool, you must say, he is weak, is a gallant pocky, you must say, he has the court scab, come she is your mistress or so:
Come Siren your voice.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Will not you stay in mine bosom tonight love?

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: By no means sweet breast, this Gentleman has vowed to see me chastely laid.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: He shall have a bed too, if that it please him.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Peace you tender him offence, he is one of a professed abstinence, Siren your voice and away.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: The dark is my delight,
So it is the Nightingales.
My Music is in the night,
So is the Nightingales.
My body is but little,
So is the Nightingales.
I love to sleep against prickle.
So doth the Nightingale.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Thanks, Busse, so the night grows old good rest.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Rest to mine dear love, rest, and no long absence.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Believe me not long.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Shall I not believe you long.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: O yes, come viah, away, boy, on.

div2.stage: Enter Freuill and seemes to ouerheare Malheureus.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Is she unchaste, can such a one be damned?
O love and beauty, ye two eldest seeds
Of the vast Chaos, what strong right you have,
Even in things divine, our very souls.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Wha, ha, ho, come bird come, stand peace.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Are strumpets then such things, so delicate,
Can custom spoil, what nature made so good.
Or is their Custom bad? Beauty is for use,
I never saw a sweet face vicious,
It might be proud, inconstant, wanton, nice,
But never tainted with unnatural vice.
Their worst is, their best art is love to win,
"O that to love should be or shame, or sin;

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: By the Lord he is caught, Laughter eternal?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Soul I must love her destiny is weak to my affection.
A common love, blush not faint breast
That which is ever loved of most is best,
Let colder eld the strongest objections move,
No love is without some lust, o life without some love.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Nay come on good sir, what though the most odious spectacle the world can present be an immodest vulgar woman:
Yet sir for my sake.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Well sir for your sake I will think better of them.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: Do good sir and pardon me that have brought you in
You know the sight of vice augments the hate of sin.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Ha? will you go home sir it is high bed time.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: Withal my heart sir only do not chide me
I must confess.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: A wanton lover you have been.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: O that to love should be or shame, or sin.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Say ye?

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: Let colder eld the strongest objections move.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: How is this?

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: No love is without some lust,
No life without some love,
go your ways for an Apostate, I believe my cast garment must be let out in the seams for you when all is done,
"Of all the fools that would all man out-thrust,
"He that against Nature would seem wise is worst.

div2.stage: Enter Ereeuile, pages with torches, and gentlemen with musicke.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: The morn is yet but young: here gentlemen,
This is my Beatrice window, this the chamber
Of my betrothed dearest, whose chaste eyes,
Full of loved sweetness, and clear cheerfulness,
Have gaged my soul to her in joyings,
Shredding away all those weak under branches,
Of base affections, and unfruitful heats,
Here bestow your music to my voice.
Always a virtuous name to my chaste love,

sp.speaker: Bea:
sp.l: Loved sir the honour of your wish return to you,
I cannot with a mistress complement
Forced discourses, or nice art of wit,
Give entertain to your dear wished presence,
But safely thus, what hearty gratefulness,
Unsullen Silence, unaffected modesty,
And an unignorant shamefastness can express,
Receive as your protested due. Faith my heart,
I am your servant,
O let not my secure simplicity, breed your mislike,
As one quite void of skill,
It is Grace enough in us not to be ill,
I can some good, and faith I mean no hurt,
Do not then sweet wrong sober ignorance,
I judge you all of virtue, and our vows,
Should kill all fears that base distrust can move,
my soul what say you, still you love?

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: Still? my vow is up above me, and like time
Irrevocable. I am sworn all yours,
No beauty shall untwine our arms, no face
In my eyes can or shall seem fair ,
And would to God only to me you might
Seem only fair; let others disesteem
Your matchless graces: so might I safer seem,
Envy I covet not: far, far be all ostent
Vain boasts of beauties: soft joys and the rest,
He that is wise, pants, on a private breast,
So could I live in desert most unknown,
Yourself to me enough were Populous,
Your eyes shall be my joys, my wine that still
Shall drown my often cares, your only voice
Shall cast a slumber on my listening sense,
You with soft lip shall only ope mine eyes,
And suck their lids asunder , only you
Shall make me wish to live, and not fear death,
So on your cheeks I might yield latest breath,
O he that thus may live, and thus shall die,
May well be envied of a deity.

sp.speaker: Beat:
sp.p: Dear my loved heart be not so passionate, nothing extreme lives long.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: But not to be extreme, nothing in love is extreme my love receives no mean.

sp.speaker: Beat:
sp.l: I give you faith, and pre thee since poor soul I am so easy to believe thee, make it much more pity to deceive me, wear this sleight favour in my remembrance.

div2.stage: throweth downe a ring to him.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: Which when I part from,
hope the best of life, ever part from me.

sp.speaker: Beat:
sp.p: I take you and your word, which may ever live your servant, see day is quite broke up , the best of hours.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Good morrow graceful mistress, our nuptial day holds.

sp.speaker: Beat:
sp.p: With happy constancy a wished day.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Myself and all content rest with you.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: The studious morn with paler cheek draws on,
The days bold light. hark how the free-born birds
Carol their unaffected passions,

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Now sing they sonnets, thus they cry, we love
O breath of heaven! thus they harmless souls
Give entertain to mutual affects.
They have no Bawds: no mercenary beds
No politic restraints: no artificial heats
No faint dissemblings, no custom makes them blush,
No shame afflicts their name, O you happy beasts
In whom an inborn heat is not held sin,
How far transcend you wretched, wretched man
Whom national custom, Tyrannous respects
Of slavish order, fetters: lames his power
Calling that sin in us, which in all things else
Is natures highest virtue. (O miseri quorum gaudia crimen habent.)
Sure nature against virtue cross doth fall
Or virtues self is oft unnatural,
That I should love a strumpet I a man of Snow
Now shame forsake me whether am I fallen?
A creature of a public use, my friends love too
To live to be a talk to men, a shame
To my professed virtue. "O accursed reason,
"How many eyes hast thou to see thy shame
"And yet how blind once to prevent defame!

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Diaboli virtus in Lumbis est, morrow my friend: come, could make a tedious scene of this now but, what, pah, thou art in love with a Courtesan, why sir, should we loath all strumpets sum men should hate their own mothers or sisters, a sin against kind I can tell you.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: May it beseem a wise man to be in love?

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Let wise men alone, it will beseem thee and me well enough.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Shall I not offend the vow band of our friendship?

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: What to affect that which thy friend affected? by heaven I resign her freely, the creature and I must grow of, by this time she has assuredly heard of my resolved marriage, and no question swears, Gods Sacrament, ten Thousand Devils I will resign I'faith.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: I would but embrace her, hear her speak, and at the most but kiss her.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: O friend he that could live with the smoke of roast meat might live at a cheap rate.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: I shall never prove heartily received,
A kind of flat ungracious modesty,
An insufficient dullness stains my behaviour.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: No matter sir, in-sufficiency and sottishness are much commendable in a most discommendable action, now could I swallow thee, thou hadst wont to be so harsh and cold, I will tell thee.
sp.l: Hell and the prodigies of angry Jove
are not so fearful to a thinking mind
as a man without affection, why friend,
Philosophy and nature are all one,
love is the centre in which all lines close
the common bond of being.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: O but a chaste reserved privateness, a modest continence.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: I will tell thee what, take this as firmest sense,
Incontinence will force a Continence,
"Heat wasteth heat, light defaceth light,
"Nothing is spoiled but by his proper might,
This is some thing too weighty for thy floor.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: But howsoever you shade it, the worlds eye
Shines hot and open on it,
Lying, malice, envy, are held but slidings,
Errors of rage, when custom and the world
Calls lust a crime spotted with blackest terrors.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Where errors are held Crimes, Crimes are but errors. Along sir to her she is an arrant strumpet:and a strumpet is. A Sarpego: Venomed Gonory to man

div2.stage: Offer to go out & suddenly draws backe.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Things actually possessed: yet since thou art in love
And again as good make use of a Statue,
A body without a soul, a carcass three months dead,
Yet since thou art in love.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Death man, my destiny I cannot choose.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Nay I hope so, again they sell but only flesh,
No jot affection, so that even in the enjoying,
Absentem marmore amque puts, yet since you needs must love .

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Unavoidable though folly, worse than madness.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: It is true, but since you needs must love ,you must know this,
He that must love, a fool, and he must kiss,
sp.p: M. Cocledemoy vt vales Domine.

sp.speaker: Cocle:
sp.p: Ago tibigratias, my worshipful friend, how does your friend?

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Out you rascal.

sp.speaker: Cocle:
sp.p: Hang toasts, you are an Ass, much a your worships brain lies in your Calves, bread a God boy, I was at supper last night with a new weened bulchin, bread a God; drunk, horribly drunk, horribly drunk, there was a wench one Franke Frailty, a punk, an honest pole cat, of a clean In-step, sound leg, smooth thigh, and the nimble Devil in her buttock, ah fiest a grace, when saw you Tysefew, or M. Caqueture, that prattling gallant of a good draught, common customs, fortunate, impudence and sound fare.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Away Rogue.

sp.speaker: Cocle:
sp.p: Hang toasts, my fine boy, my companion as worshipful.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Yes I hear you are taken up with scholars and churchmen.

sp.speaker: Cocle:
sp.p: Quanquam te Marce fili my fine boy; does your worship want a Barber Surgeon?

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Farewell knave, beware the Mulligrubs.

sp.speaker: Cocle:
sp.p: Let the Mulligrubs beware the knave, what a Barber Surgeon my delicate boy?

sp.speaker: Holof.
sp.p: Yes sir an apprentice to surgery.
It is my fine boy, to what bawdy house doth your Master belong, what is thy name?

sp.speaker: Holof.
sp.p: Holifernes Rain scure.

sp.speaker: Cocle:
sp.p: Rainscure? good M. Holifernes I desire your further acquaintance, nay pray ye be covered my fine boy, kill thy itch and heal thy scabs, is thy Master rotten?

sp.speaker: Holof.
sp.p: My father forsooth is dead.

sp.speaker: Cocle:
sp.p: And laid in his grave, alas what comfort shall Peggy then have .

sp.speaker: Holof.
sp.p: None but me sir, that is my mothers son I assure you.

sp.speaker: Cocle:
sp.p: Mothers son, a good witty boy, would live to read an Homily well, and to whom are you going now?

sp.speaker: Holof.
sp.p: Marry forsooth to trim M. Mulligrub the Vintner.

sp.speaker: Cocle:
sp.p: Do you know M. Mulligrub?

sp.speaker: Holof.
sp.p: My Godfather Sir.

sp.speaker: Cocle:
sp.p: Good boy hold up thy chops, I pray thee do one thing for me, my name is Gudgeon.

sp.speaker: Holof.
sp.p: good M. Gudgeon.

sp.speaker: Cocle:
sp.p: Lend me thy basin, razor, and Apron.

sp.speaker: Holof.
sp.p: O Lord sir.

sp.speaker: Cocle:
sp.p: Well spoke, good english, but what is thy furniture worth?

sp.speaker: Holof.
sp.p: O Lord sir I know not.

sp.speaker: Cocle:
sp.p: Well spoken, a boy of a good wit, hold this pawn, where dost dwell.

sp.speaker: Holof.
sp.p: At the sign of the three razors sir.

sp.speaker: Cocle:
sp.p: A sign of good shaving my catastrophically fine boy, I have an odd jest to trim M. Mulligrub for a wager, a jest boy, a humour, I will return thy things presently, hold.

sp.speaker: Holof.
sp.p: What mean you good M. Gudgeon?

sp.speaker: Cocle:
sp.p: Nothing faith but a jest boy, drink that, I will recoil presently.

sp.speaker: Holof.
sp.p: You will not stay long.

sp.speaker: Cocle:
sp.p: As I am an honest man, the three razors?

sp.speaker: Holof.
sp.p: Aye sir.

sp.speaker: Cocle:
sp.p: Good, and if shave not M. Mulligrub, my wit has no edge, and I may go cack in my pewter, let me see, a Barber, my Scurvy tongue will discover me, must dissemble, must disguise, for my beard, my false hair, for my tongue Spanish Dutch, or Welsh, no, a Northern Barber, very good, widow Raine-scures man well, newly entertained, right, to, hang toasts, all.cards have white backs, and all knaves would seem to have white breasts, so proceed, now worshipful Cocledemoy.

div2.stage: Exit Cocledemoy in his Barbars furniture.
Enter Marie Eough, and Erancischina with her Harye, Loose chafing.

sp.speaker: Mar:
sp.p: Nay good sweet daughter, do not swagger so, you hear your love is to be married, true, he does cast you off, right he will leave you to the world, what then? though blue and white, black and green leave you, may not red and yellow entertain you, is there but one colour in the Rainbow?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Grand Grincome on your sentences, Gods sacrament, ten thousand devils take you, you have brought mine love, mine honour, mine body all to nothing.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: To nothing I will be sworn I have brought them to all the things I could, I have made as much a your maidenhead and you had been mine own daughter, I could not have sold your Maiden head oftener than I have done, I have sworn for you God forgive me, I have made you acquainted with the Spaniard Don Skirtoll, with the Italian, M. Beieroane, with the Irish Lord, Saint Patrick, with the Dutch Merchant, Haunce Herkin Glukin Skellam Flappdragon, and specially with the greatest French, and now lastly with this English (yet in my conscience) an honest Gentleman: and am I now grown one of the accursed with you for my labour? is this my reward, am I called Bawd? Well Mary Fough, go thy ways Mary Fough, thy kind heart will bring thee to the Hospital.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Nay good Naunt, you will help me to another love, will you not?

sp.speaker: Mar:
sp.p: Out thou naughty belly, wouldst thou make me thy Bawd? thou hadst best make me thy Bawd, I have kept counsel for thee, who paid the Apothecary, wast not honest Mary Fough? who redeemed thy petticoat and mantle, wast not honest Mary Fough? who helped thee to thy custom not of swaggering Ireland Captains, nor of two shillings Inns a court men, but with honest atte-cappes, wealthy flat caps, that pay for their pleasure the best of any men in Europe, nay, which is more in London, and dost thou defy me vile creature.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Foutra pon you Witch, Bawd, Pole cat, Paugh, did not you praise Freeuill to mine love?

sp.speaker: Mar:
sp.p: I did praise I confess, I did praise him, I said he was a fool, an unthrift, a true whoremaster, I confess, a constant drab keeper I confess, but what the wind is turned.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: It is, it is vile woman, reprobate woman, naughty woman it is, what shall become of mine poor flesh now, mine body must turn Turk for twopence O Divela, life a mine art, I shall be revenged, do ten thousand Hell damn me, I shall have the rouge trote cut, and his love, and his friend, and all his affinity shall smart, shall die, shall hang, now legion of devil seize him, the gran pest, Saint Anthonies fire, and the hot Neopolitan poc rot him.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Francischina.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: O mine sweet, dearest, kindest, mine loving, O mine thousand, ten thousand, delicated, petty sweet art
a mine a dear leeuest affection.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Why Monkey, no fashion in you? give entertain to my friend.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: mine Mettre sing another song, frolic, frolic Sir, but still complain me do her wrong, lighten your heart Sir, for me did but kiss her, for me did but kiss her, and so let go:
sp.p: Your friend is very heavy, I shall never like such sad company.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: No thou delightest only in light Company.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: By mine trot, he been very sad, what ail you sir.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: A tooth ache Lady, a paltry rheum.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: The diet is very good for the rheum.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: How far off dwells the house surgeon Mary Fough.

sp.speaker: Mar:
sp.p: You are a profane fellow I'faith, I little thought to hear such ungodly terms come from your lips.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Pre thee now, it is but a toy, a very trifle.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: I care not for the value, Franke, but I'faith

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: I'faith, me must needs have it (this is Beatrice ring, O could I get it,) sweet pree thee now, as ever you have embraced me with a hearty arm, a warm thought, or a pleasing touch, as ever you will profess to love me, as ever you do wish me life, give me this ring, this little ring.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Pree thee be not uncivilly importunate, shall not have it, faith I care not for thee, nor thy jealousy, shall not have it i'faith.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: You do not love me, I hear of Sir Hubert Subboys daughter Mistress Beatrice, Gods Sacrament, I could scratch out her eyes, and suck the holes.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Go you are grown a punk rampant.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: So get thee gone,never more behold mine eyes by thee made wretched.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Mary Fough farewell, farewell Franck.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Shall I not have the ring?

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: No by the Lord.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: By the Lord?

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: By the Lord.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Go to your new Blouse, your unproved sluttery, your modest Mettre forsooth.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Marry will I forsooth.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Will you marry forsooth?

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Do not turn witch before thy time.
With all my heart Sir, you will stay.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: I am no whit myself, Viaco melior a proboque,
But raging lust my fate all strong doth move:
"The Gods themselves cannot be wise and love.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Your wishes to you.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Beauty entirely choice:

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Pray ye prove a man of fashion, and neglect the neglected.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Can such a rarity be neglected, can there be measure or sin in loving such a creature.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: O mine poor forsaken heart.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: I cannot contain, he saw thee not that left thee,
If there be wisdom, reason, honour, grace
Of any foolishly esteemed virtue,
In giving over possession of such beauty,
Let me be vicious, so I may be loved,
Passion I am thy slave, sweet it shall be my grace,
That I account thy love, my only virtue:
Shall I swear I am thy most vowed servant.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Mine vowed, go, go, go, I can no more of love, no, no, no, you been all unconstant, O unfaithful men, tyrants, betrayers, thee very enjoying us, loseth us, and when you only have made us hateful, you only hate us: O mine forsaken heart.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: I must not rave, Silence and modesty two customary virtues: will you be my mistress?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Mettres? ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Will you lie with me?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Lie with you, O no, you men will out-lie any woman, faith me no more can love.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: No matter, let me enjoy your bed.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: O vile man, what do you think on me, do you take me to be a beast, a creature that for sense only will entertain love, and not only for love, love? O brutish abomination!

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Why then I pray thee love, and with thy love enjoy me.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Give me reason to affect you, will you swear you love me.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: So seriously, that I protest no office so dangerous, no deed so unreasonable, no cost so heavy, but I vow to the utmost tentation of my best being to effect it.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Shall I, or can I trust again? O fool,
How natural it is for us to be abused
Shal I be sure that no satiety,
No inoying, not time shall languish your affection?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: If there be aught in brain, heart or hand,
Can make you doubtless, I am your vowed servant.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Will you do one ting for me?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Can I do it?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Yes, yes, but I do not love this same Freeuill.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Well.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Nay I do hate him.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: So.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: By this kiss I hate him.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: I love to feel such oaths, swear again.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: No, no, did you ever hear of any that loved at the first sight?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: A thing most proper.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Now faith, I judge it all incredible,until this hour I saw you pretty fair eyed youth, would you enjoy me? I

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Rather than my breath, even as my being.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Well, had I not made a vow.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: What vow?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: O let me forget it, it makes us both despair.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Dear soul what vow?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Ha, good morrow gentle Sir, endeavour to forget me, as I must be enforced to forget all men. Sweet mind rest in you.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Stay, let not my desire burst me, O my impatient here endures no resistance, no protraction, there is no being for me but your sudden enjoying.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: I do not love Freeuil.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: But what vow, what vow?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: So long as Freeuil lives, I must not love .

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Then he.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Must.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Die.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Aye , No there is no such vehemence in your affects,
Would I were anything, so he were not.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Will you be mine when he is not?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Will I? dear, dear breast, by this most zealous kiss, but I will not persuade you:but if you hate him that I loath most deadly, yet as you please, I will persuade nothing.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Will you be only mine.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Will I? how hard it is for true love to dissemble, I am only yours.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: It is as irrevocable as breath, he dies. Your love .

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: My vow, not until he be dead,
Which that I may be sure not to infringe,
This token of his death, shall satisfy,
He has a ring, as dear as the air to him,
His new loves gift: that got and brought to me.
I shall assured your professed rest.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: To kill a man?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: O done safely, a quarrel sudden picked,
with an advantage strike, then bribe, a little coin,
All is safe dear soul, but I will not set you on,

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Nay he is gone, the ring, well, come, little more liberal of thy love.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Not yet my vow.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: O heaven, there is no hell but loves prolongings, dear farewell.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Farewell, Now does my heart swell high, for my revenge,
Has birth and form, first friend shall kill his friend,
He that survives, I will hang, besides thee
Chaste Beatrice I will vex only the ring.
That got the world shall know the worst of evils.
"Woman corrupted is the worst of devils.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: To kill my friend O it is to kill myself,
Yet man is but man's excrement, man breeding man,
As he does worms or this, to spoil this nothing,

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: The body of a man is of the self same soul,
As Ox or horse, no murther to kill these,
As for that only part, which makes us man,
Murther wants power to touched. O wit how vile,
How hellish art thou, when thou raisest nature
Against sacred faith think more to kill a friend
To gain a woman, to lose a virtuous self,
For appetite and sensual end, whose very having ,
Loseth all appetite, and gives satiety,
That corporal end, remorse and inward blushings,
Forcing us loath the steam of our own heats,
Whilst friendship closed in virtue being spiritual,
Tastes no such languishings and moments pleasure,
With much repentance, but like rivers flow,
And further that they run, they bigger grow,
Lord how was I misgone, how easy it is to err,
When passion will not give us leave to think!
"A learned that is an honest man may fear.
"And lust, and rage, and malice, and anything,
"when he is taken uncollected suddenly:
"It is sin of cold blood, mischief with waked eyes;
"That is the damned and the truly vice,
"Not he that is passionless but he above passion is wise,
My friend shall know it all.

div2.stage: Enter Maister Mulligrub, and Mistresse Mulligrub, shee with bag of money.

sp.speaker: Mistresse Mul.
sp.p: It is right I assure you, just fifteen pounds.

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.p: Well Cocledemoy it is thou puttest me to this charge, but if I catch thee, I will charge thee with as many irons: well, is the Barber come, I will be trimmed and then to Cheapside, to buy a fair piece of plate, to furnish the loss, is the Barber come?

sp.speaker: Mist: Mull.
sp.p: Truth husband, surely heaven is not pleased with our vocation; we do wink at the sins of our people, our wines are Protestants, and I speak it to my grief, and to the burthen of my conscience, we fry our fish with salt butter.

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.p: Go look to your business, mend the matter and score false with a vengeance.

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.p: Welcome friend, whose man?

sp.speaker: Cocle:
sp.p: Widow Raine-scures man, and shall please your good worship, my name is Andrew Sharke.

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.p: How does my God son good Androw?

sp.speaker: Cocle:
sp.p: Very well, he is gone to trim M. Quicquid our Parson, hold up your head.

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.p: How long have you been a Barber Andrew?

sp.speaker: Cocle:
sp.p: Not long Sir, this two year.

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.p: What and a good work man already, I dare scarce trust my head to thee.

sp.speaker: Cocle:
sp.p: O fear not, we have poled better men than you, we learn, the trade very quickly, will your good worship be shaven or cut?

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.p: As you will, what trade didst live by, before thou turnedest Barber Andrew

sp.speaker: Cocle:
sp.p: I was a Peddler in Germany, but my countrymen thrive better by this trade.

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.p: What is the news Barber, thou art sometimes at Court.

sp.speaker: Cocle:
sp.p: Sometimes pole a Page or so sir.

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.p: And what is the news? how do all my good Lords and all my good Ladies, and all the rest of my acquaintance.

sp.speaker: Cocle:
sp.p: What an arrogant knave is this, I will acquaintance ye (it is cash,) say ye sir.

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.p: And what news? what news? good Andrew.

sp.speaker: Cocle:
sp.p: Marry sir you know the Conduit at Greenwich, and the under holes that spouts up water.

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.p: Very well, I was washed there one day, and so was my wife, you might have wrung her smock i'faith, but what a those holes?

sp.speaker: Cocle:
sp.p: Thus Sir, out of those little holes in the midst of the night crawled out twenty-four huge horrible, monstrous, fearful devouring.

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.p: Bless us.

sp.speaker: Cocle:
sp.p: Serpents, which no sooner were beheld, but they turned to mastiffs which howled, those mastiffs instantly turned to Cocks which crowed, those cocks in a moment were changed to Bears which roared, which Bears are at this hour to be yet seen in Paris Garden, living upon nothing but toasted cheese and green onions.

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.p: By the Lord and this may be: my wife and I will go see them, this portends something.

sp.speaker: Cocle:
sp.p: Yes worshipful Fiest, thou hast feel what portends by and by.

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.p: And what more news, you shave the world, especially you Barber Surgeons you know the ground of many things, you are cunning privy searchers, by the mass you scour all: what more news?

sp.speaker: Cocle:
sp.p: They say Sir that twenty-five, couple of Spanish Jennets are to be seen hand in hand dance the old measures, whilst six goodly Flanders Mares play to them on a noise of flutes.

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.p: O monstrous! this is a lie a my word, nay and this be not a lie, I am no fool I warrant, nay make an Ass of me once?

sp.speaker: Cocle:
sp.p: Shut your eyes close, wink sure sir, this ball will make you smart.

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.p: I do wink.

sp.speaker: Cocle:
sp.p: Your head will take cold.
sp.stage: Cocledemoy puts on a Coxe combe on Mulligrubs head.
sp.p: I will put on your good worships night cap, whilst I shave you, so, mum: hang toasts: faugh: viah: sparrows must peck and Cocledemoy munch.

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, twenty-fivecouple of Spanish Jennets to dance the old measures. Andrew, makes my worship laugh, i'faith, dost take me for an Ass Andrew, dost know one Cocledemoy in town, he made me an Ass last night, but I will ass him, art thou free Andrew, shave me well, I shall be one of the common Council shortly, and then Andrew, why Andrew, Andrew, dost leave me in the Suds?
why Andrew I shall be blind with winking. Ha Andrew, wife Andrew, what means this, wife, my money wife.

sp.speaker: Mistresse Mull.
sp.p: What is the noise with you? what ail you?

sp.speaker: M. Mull.
sp.p: Where is the Barber?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mull.
sp.p: Gone, I saw him depart long since, why are not you trimmed?

sp.speaker: M. Mull.
sp.p: Trimmed, O wife, I am shaved, did you take hence the money?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mull.
sp.p: I touched it not as I am Religious.

sp.speaker: M. Mull.
sp.p: O Lord I have winked fair.

sp.speaker: Holof.
sp.p: I pray Godfather give me your blessing.

sp.speaker: M. Mull.
sp.p: O Holofernes, O where is thy mothers Andrew?

sp.speaker: Holof.
sp.p: Blessing Godfather.

sp.speaker: M. Mull.
sp.p: The devil choke thee, where is Andrew thy mothers man?

sp.speaker: Holof.
sp.p: My mother hath none such forsooth.

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.p: My money, fifteen pounds plague of all Andrewes, who was it trimmed me?

sp.speaker: Holof.
sp.p: I know not Godfather, only one met me, as I was coming to you, and borrowed my furniture, as he said for a jest sake.

sp.speaker: M. Mul.
sp.p: What kind of fellow?

sp.speaker: Holof.
sp.p: A thick elderly stub-bearded fellow.

sp.speaker: M. Mul.
sp.p: Cocledemoy, Cocledemoy, raise all, the Wise men in the street, I will hang him with mine own hands: O wife, some Rosa Solis.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mull.
sp.p:
Good husband take comfort in the Lord, I will play the Devil, but I will recover it, have a good conscience it is but a
weeks cutting in the Term.

sp.speaker: M. Mul.
sp.p: O wife, O wife, O Iacke how does thy mother? is there any Fiddlers in the house?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mull.
sp.p: Yes, M. Creakes noise.

sp.speaker: M Mull.
sp.p: Bid them play, laugh, make merry, cast up my accounts, for I will go hang myself presently, I will not curse, but a pox on Cocledemoy, he has poled and shaved me, he has trimmed me.

div2.stage: Enter Beatrice, Crispinell, and Nurs Putifer.

sp.speaker: Puti.
sp.p: Nay good child, A love once more, M. Freeuils Sonnet, a the kiss you gave him.

sp.speaker: Bea:
sp.p: Shalt have it good Nurse,
sp.l: Purest lips soft banks of blisses,
Self alone, deserving kisses:
O give me leave to, etcetera

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.p: Pish sister Beatrice, pree thee read no more, my stomach a-late stands against kissing extremely.

sp.speaker: Bea:
sp.p: Why good Crispinella?

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.p: By the faith, and trust I bear to my face, it is grown one of the most unsavoury Ceremonies: Body, a beauty it is one of the most unpleasing injurious customs to Ladies: any fellow that has but one nose on his face, and standing colour and skirts also lined with Taffeta sarsenet, must salute us on the lips as familiarly: Soft skins save us, there was a stub-bearded Iohn a style with a ploydens face saluted me last day, and stroke his bristles through my lips, I have spent ten shillings in pomatum since to skin them again. Marry if a nobleman or a knight with one lock visit us though his vncleave goose turned green teeth, have the palsy, his nostrils smell worse then a putrefied marrowbone, and his loose beard drops into our bosom, yet we must kiss him with a curtsy, a curse, for my part I had as live they would break wind in my lips.

sp.speaker: Bea:
sp.p: Fie Crispinella you speak too broad.

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.p: No jot sister, let us never be ashamed to speak what we be not ashamed to think, I dare as boldly speak venery, as think, venery.

sp.speaker: Bea:
sp.p: Faith sister I will begone if you speak so broad.

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.p: Will you so? now bashfulness seize you, we pronounce boldly Robbery, Murder, treason, which deeds must needs be far more loathsome than an act which is so natural, just and necessary, as that of procreation, you shall have an hypocritical vestal virgin speak, that with close teeth publicly, which she will receive with open mouth privately, for my own part I consider nature without apparel, without disguising of custom or complement, I give thoughts words, and words truth, and truth boldness, she whose honest freeness makes it her virtue, to speak what she thinks, will make it her necessity to think what is good, I love no prohibited things, and yet I would have nothing prohibited by policy but by virtue, for as in the fashion of time, those books that are called in, are most in sale and request; so in nature those actions that are most prohibited, are most desired.

sp.speaker: Bea:
sp.p: Good quick sister, stay your pace we are private, but the world would censure you, for truly severe modesty is women's virtue.

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.p: Fie, Fie, virtue is a free pleasant buxom quality: I love a constant countenance well, but this froward ignorant coins, sour austere lumpish uncivil privateness, that promises nothing but rough skins, and hard stools, ha, fie on it good for nothing but for nothing, well nurse, and what do you conceive of all this?

sp.speaker: Puti.
sp.p: Nay faith my conceiving days be done, marry for kissing I will defend that, that is within my compass, but for my own part here is mistress Beatruce is to be married with the grace of God, a fine gentleman he is shall have her and I warrant a strong, he has a leg like a post, a nose like a Lion, a brow like a Bull, and a beard of most fair expectation: this week you must marry him, and I now will read a lecture to you both, how you shall behave yourselves to your husbands, the first month of your nuptial, I have broke my skull about it, I can tell you and there is much brain in it.

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.p: Read it to my sister good nurse, for I assure you I will never marry.

sp.speaker: Puti.
sp.p: Marry God forfend, what will you do then?

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.p: Faith strive against the flesh, marry? no faith, husbands are like lots in the lottery: you may draw forty blanks before you find one that has any prise in him, A husband generally is a careless domineering thing that grows like coral which as long as it is under water is soft and tender, but as soon as it has got his branch above the waves is presently hard stiff, not to be bowed but burst, so when your husband is a suitor and under your choice, Lord how supple he is, how obsequious, how at your service sweet Lady: once married got up his head above A stiff crooked knobby inflexible tyrannous creature he grows then they turn like water, more you would embrace the less you hold, I will live my own woman, and if the worst come to the worst, I had rather prove a wag than a fool.

sp.speaker: Bea:
sp.p: O but a virtuous marriage.

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.p: Virtuous marriage? there is no more affinity betwixt virtue and marriage, than betwixt a man and his horse, indeed virtue, gets up upon marriage sometimes, and manageth it in the right way, but marriage is of another piece, for as a horse may be without a man, and a man without a horse, so marriage you know is often without virtue, and virtue I am sure more oft without marriage, but thy match sister, by my troth I think it will do well, he is a well shaped clean lipped gentleman of a handsome, but not affected fineness, a good faithful eye, and a well humoured cheek, would he did not stoop in the shoulders for thy sake, see here he is.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Good day Sweet.

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.p: Good morrow brother nay you shall have my lip, good morrow servant.

sp.speaker: Tysep.
sp.p: Good morrow sweet life.

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.p: Life? dost call thy mistress life.

sp.speaker: Tysep.
sp.p: Life,yes why not life?

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.p: How many mistresses hast thou?

sp.speaker: Tysep.
sp.p: Some nine.

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.p: Why then thou hast nine lives like a Cat.

sp.speaker: Tysep.
sp.p: Mew you would be taken up for that.

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.p: Nay good let me still sit, we low statures love still to sit, lest when we stand we may be supposed to sit.

sp.speaker: Tysep.
sp.p: Dost not wear high cork shoes: choppiness.

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.p: Monstrous ones. I am as many other are, pieced above and pieced beneath.

sp.speaker: Tysep.
sp.p: Still the best part in the ~~

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.p: And yet all will scarce make me so high as one of the Giants stilts that stalks before my Lord Mayors pageant.

sp.speaker: Tysep.
sp.p: By the Lord so I thought it was for some thing Mistress Ioyce jested at thy high insteps.

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.p: She might well enough, and long enough, before I would be ashamed of my shortness, what I made or can mend myself I may blush at; but what nature put upon me, let her be ashamed for me, I have nothing to do with it, I forget my beauty.

sp.speaker: Tysep.
sp.p: Faith Ioyce is a foolish bitter creature.

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.p: A pretty mildewed wench she is.

sp.speaker: Tysep.
sp.p: And fair.

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.p: As myself.

sp.speaker: Tysep.
sp.p: O you forget your beauty now.

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.p: Troth I never remember my beauty, but as some men do religion for controversies sake,

sp.speaker: Bea:
sp.p: A motion sister.

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.p: Niniuie, Iulius Caesar, Ionas, or the destruction of Jerusalem.

sp.speaker: Bea:
sp.p: My love here.

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.p: Pree thee call him not love, it is the drabs phrase, nor sweet honey, nor my cony, nor dear duckling, it is the Citizen terms, but call me him.

sp.speaker: Bea:
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.p: Anything, what is the motion?

sp.speaker: Bea:
sp.p: You know this night our parents have intended solemnly to contract us, and my Love to grace the feast hath promised a mask.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: You will make one Tysefue, and Caqueture shall fill up a room.

sp.speaker: Tysep.
sp.p: Fore heaven well remembered he borrowed a diamond of me last night to grace his finger in your visitation: The Lying Creature will swear some strange thing on it now.

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.p: Peace, he is here, stand close, lurk.

sp.speaker: Caque.
sp.p: Good morrow most dear, and worthy to be most wise, how does my mistress?

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.p: Morrow sweet servant, you glister, pree thee let us see that stone.

sp.speaker: Caque.
sp.p: A toy Lady, I bought to please my finger.

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.p: Why I am more precious to you, than your finger:

sp.speaker: Caque.
sp.p: Yes, or than all my body, I swear.

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.p: Why, then let it be bought to please me, come I am no professed beggar.

sp.speaker: Caque.
sp.p: Troth Mistress; 'swounds: Forsooth, I protest.

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.p: Nay, if you turn Protestant for such a toy.

sp.speaker: Caque.
sp.p: In good deed la, another time I will give you a

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.p: Is this yours to give.

sp.speaker: Caque.
sp.p: O God, forsooth mine, quoth you, nay as for that.

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.p: Now I remember, I have seen this on my servant Tisefewes finger.

sp.speaker: Caque.
sp.p: Such another.

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.p: Nay, I am sure this is it.

sp.speaker: Caque.
sp.p: Troth it is forsooth, the poor fellow wanted money to pay for supper last night, and so pawned it to me, it is a pawn i'faith, or else you should have it.

sp.speaker: Tysep.
sp.p: Hark ye, Thou base lying: how dares thy impudence hope to prosper, were it not for the privilege of this respected company, I would so hang thee.

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.p: Come hither servant, What is the matter betwixt you two?

sp.speaker: Caque.
sp.p: Nothing but (hark you) he did me some uncivil discourtesies last night, for which, because I should not call him to account, he desires to make me any satisfaction: the Coward trembles at my very presence, but I have him on the hip, I will take the forfeit on his Ringe.

sp.speaker: Tysep.
sp.p: What is that you whisper to her?

sp.speaker: Caque.
sp.p: Nothing Sir, but satisfy her, that the Ringe was not pawned, but only lent by you to grace my finger, and so told her I craved your pardon, for being too familiar, or indeed overbold with your reputation.

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.p: Yes indeed he did, he said you desired to make him any satisfaction for an uncivil discourtesy you did him last night, but he said he had you a the hip and would take the forfeit of your ring.

sp.speaker: Tysep.
sp.p: How now ye base Poltroon?

sp.speaker: Caque.
sp.p: Hold, hold, my mistress speaks by contraries.

sp.speaker: Tysep.
sp.p: Contraries.

sp.speaker: Caque.
sp.p: She jests, faith only jests.

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.p: Sir, I will no more a your service, you are a child, I will give you to my nurse.

sp.speaker: Puti.
sp.p: And he come to me, I can tell you as old as I am, what to do with him.

sp.speaker: Caque.
sp.p: I offer my service forsooth.

sp.speaker: Tysep.
sp.p: Why so, now every dog has his bone to gnaw on.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: The Mask holds, Master Caqueteur.

sp.speaker: Caque.
sp.p: I am ready Sir, Mistress I will dance with you, never fear, I will grace you.

sp.speaker: Puti.
sp.p: I tell you I can my singles and my doubles and my trick a twenty, my carantapace, my traverse forward, and my falling back yet i'faith.

sp.speaker: Bea:
sp.p: Mine, the provision for the night is ours.
Much must be our care, till night we leave you,
I am your servant be not tyrannous,
Your virtue wan me, faith my loves not lust,
Good wrong me not, my most fault is much trust.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Until night only my heart be with you. Farewell sister.

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.p: Adieu brother, come on sister for these sweet meats.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Let us meet and practise presently.

sp.speaker: Tysep.
sp.p: Content, we will but fit our pumps, Come ye pernicious vermin.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: My friend, wished hours, what news from Babylon?
How does the woman of Sin, and natural concupiscence

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: The eldest child of nature never beheld
So damned a creature.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: What, In noua fert animus mutatas dicere formas? which way bears the Tide?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Dear loved Sir, I find a mind courageously vicious, may put on a desperate security, but can never be blessed with a firm enjoying and self satisfaction.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: what passion is this, my dear Lindabridis.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: It is well, we both may jest, I have been tempted to your death.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: What is the rampant Cockatrice grown mad for the loss of her men?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Devilishly mad.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: As most assured of my second love.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Right.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: She would have had this ring.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Aye , and this heart, and in true proof you were slain I should bring her this ring, from which she was assured
You would not part, until from life you parted.
For which deed, and only for which deed, I should possess her sweetness.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: O bloody villains, nothing is defamed but by his proper self , Physicians abuse remedies, Lawyers spoil the Law, and women only shame women, you have vowed my death?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: My lust, not I, before my reason would, yet I must use her, that I a man of sense should conceive endless pleasure in a body whose soul I know to be so hideously black.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: That a man at twenty three should cry, O sweet pleasure, and at forty three should sigh, O sharpe Pox: but consider man furnished with omnipotency and you overthrow him, thou must cool thy impatient appetite. It is Fate, it is Fate.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: I do malign my creation that I am subject to passion. I must enjoy her.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: I have it mark, I give a mask tonight
To my loves kindred, in that thou shalt go:
In that we two make show of falling out,
Give seeming challenge, instantly depart,
With some suspicion to present fight.
We will be seen as going to our swords,
And after meeting, this Ring only lent,
I will lurk in some obscure place, till rumour
(The common Bawd to loose suspicions)
Have feigned me slain, which (in respect my self
Will not be found, and our late seeming quarrel)
Will quickly sound to all as earnest truth:
Then to thy wench, protest me surely dead.
Show her this Ring, enjoy her, and blood cold
We will laugh at folly.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: O but think of it.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: Think of it, come away, virtue let sleep thy passions,
"What old times held as crimes, are now but fashions.

div2.stage: Enter Master Garnish, and Lionell: Master Mulligrubbe, with a standing cup in his hand, and an Obligation in the other, Cocledemoy stands at the other dore disguised like a French Pedler, and ouer-heares them.

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.p: I am not at this time furnished, but there is my bond for your Plate.

sp.speaker: Gar:
sp.p: Your bill had been sufficient you are a good man, a standing cup parcel guilt, of thiry-twoounces. eleven pound, seven shillings, the first of July, good plate, good man, good day, good all.

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.p: It is my hard fortune, I will hang the knave, no, first he shall half rot in fetters in the Dungeon, his conscience made despairful, I will hire a Knave a purpose, shall assure him he is damned, and after see him with mine own eyes, hanged without singing any Psalm. Lord that he has but one neck.

sp.speaker: Gar:
sp.p: You are too tyrannous, you will use me no further.

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.p: No Sir, lend me your servant, only to carry the plate home, I have occasion of an hours absence.

sp.speaker: Gar:
sp.p: With easy consent, sir haste and be careful,

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.p: Be very careful I pray thee to my wifes own hands.

sp.speaker: Lion:
sp.p: Secure yourself sir.

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.p: To her own hand.

sp.speaker: Lion:
sp.p: Fear not, I have delivered greater things than this, to a woman's own hand.

sp.speaker: Cocle:
sp.p:
Monsieur, please you to buy a fine delicate
ball, sweet ball; a Camphor ball.

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.p: Pre thee away.

sp.speaker: Cocle:
sp.p: One a ball to scour, a scouring ball, a ball to be shaved

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.p: For the love of god talk not of shaving, I have been shaved, mischief and 1000. devils cease him, I have been shaved.

sp.speaker: Caque.
sp.p: The Fox grows fat when he is cursed, I will shave ye smother yet, turd on a tile stone, my lips have a kind of rheum at this bole, I will have it, I will gargalize my throat with this Vintner, and when I have done with him, spit him out, I will shark, conscience does not repine, were I to bite an honest gentleman a poor grogaran poet, or a penurious Parson, that had but ten pigs tails in a twelve-month and for want of learning had but one good stool in a fortnight, I were damned beyond the works of supererogation, but to wring the whithers of my gouty barmed spigot frigging- jumbler of elements. Mulligrub, I hold it as lawful as sheep shearing, taking eggs from hens, caudles from Asses, or buttered shrimps from horses, they make no use of them, were not provided for them. And therefore worshipful Cocledemoy, hang toasts, on, in grace and virtue to proceed, only beware beware degrees, there be rounds in a ladder, and knots in a halter, ware carts, hang toasts, the common counsel has decreed it, I must draw a lot for the great Goblet.

div2.stage: Enter Mistresse Malligrub, and Lionell with a Goblet.

sp.speaker: Mist. Mull.
sp.p: Nay, I pray you stay and drink, and how does your Mistress, I know her very well, I have been inward with her, and so has many more, she was ever a good patient creature i'faith, with all my heart I will remember your master an honest man, he knew me before I was married, an honest man he is, and a crafty, he comes forward in the world well, I warrant him, and his wife is a proper woman that she is, well, she has been as proper a woman as any in Cheap, she paints now, and yet she keeps her husbands old Customers to him still. In troth a fine faced wife, in a wainscot carved seat, is a worthy ornament to a Tradesman shop, and an attractive I warrant, her husband shall find it in the custom of his ware, I will assure him, God be with you good youth, I acknowledge the receipt.

sp.speaker: Mist. Mull.
sp.p: I acknowledge all the receipt. sure, it is very well spoken, I acknowledge the receipt, thus it is to have good education and to be brought up in a Tavern, I do keep as gallant and as good company, though say it, as any she in London, Squires, Gentlemen,and Knights diet at my table, and I do lend some of them money, and full many fine men go upon my score, as simple as I stand here, and I trust them and truly they very knightly and courtly promise fair, give me very good words, and a piece of flesh when time of year serves, nay, though my husband be a Citizen and his caps made of wool, yet I have wit, and can see my good as soon as another, for I have all the thanks, my silly husband, alas, he knows nothing of it, it is I that bear, it is that must bear a brain for all.

sp.speaker: Cocle:
sp.p: Fair hour to you Mistress.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mu.
sp.p: Fair hour, fine term, faith I will score it up anon a beautiful thought to you sir.

sp.speaker: Cocle:
sp.p: Your Husband, and my Master Mr. Garnish has sent you a Jowl of fresh Salmon, and they both will come to dinner to season your new cup with the best wine, which cup your husband entreats you to send back by me, that his arms may be graved a the side, which he forgot before it was sent.

sp.speaker: Mr. Mul
sp.p: By what token, are you sent by no token? nay, I have wit.

sp.speaker: Cocle:
sp.p: He sent me by the same token, that he was dry shaved this morning.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mu.
sp.p: A sad token; but true, here sir, I pray you commend me to your Master, but especially to your Mistress, tell them they shall be most sincerely welcome.

sp.speaker: Cocle:
sp.p: Shall be most sincerely welcome, worshipful Cocledemoy, lurk close, hang toasts, be not ashamed of thy quality,every man's turd smells well in his own nose, vanish Foyst.

div2.stage: Enter Mrs.Mulligrub, with seruants and furniture for the Table.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mul.
sp.p:
Come spread these Table Diaper Napkins, and do you hear, perfume this Parlour does so smell of profane Tobacco, I could never endure this ungodly Tobacco, since one of our Elders, assured me upon his knowledge Tobacco was not used in the Congregation of the family of love: spread, spread handsomely, Lord these boys do things arsie, varsie, you show your bringing up , I was a Gentlewoman by my sisters side, I can
tell ye so methodically: methodically, I wonder where I go that word. O sir Aminadab Ruth bad me kiss him methodically, I had it somewhere, and I had it indeed.

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.p: Mind, be not desperate, I will recover all.
All things with me, shall seem honest, that can be profitable,
He must never winch, that would or thrive, or save,
To be called Niggard, cuckold, Cut-throat, Knave.

sp.speaker: Mrs.
sp.p: Are they come husband?

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.p: Who? what, how now? what feast towards in my private Parlour.

sp.speaker: Mrs.
sp.p: Pray leave your foolery, what are they come?

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.p: Come, who come?

sp.speaker: Mrs.
sp.p: You need not make it so strange?

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.p: Strange?

sp.speaker: Mrs.
sp.p: Aye strange, you know no man that sent me word, that he and his wife would come to dinner to me, and sent this Jowl of fresh Salmon before hand.

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.p: Peace, not I peace, the Messenger hath mistaken the house, let us eat it up quickly, before it be enquired for, sit to it, some vinegar, quick, some good luck yet, faith, never tasted salmon relished better, O when a man feeds at other men's cost.

sp.speaker: Mrs.
sp.p: Other men's cost? why did not you send this Jowl of Salmon.

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Mrs.
sp.p: By Master Garnish man?

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Mrs.
sp.p: Sending me word, that, he and his wife would come to dinner to me.

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.p: No, no.

sp.speaker: Mrs.
sp.p: To season my new bowl?

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.p: Bowl?

sp.speaker: Mrs.
sp.p: And withal wild me to send the bowl back:

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.p: Back?

sp.speaker: Mrs.
sp.p: That you might have your Arms graved on the side?

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.p: Ha?

sp.speaker: Mrs.
sp.p: By the same token you were dry shaven this morning before you went forth.

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.p: Pah, how this Salmon stinks.

sp.speaker: Mrs.
sp.p: And thereupon sent the bowl back, prepared dinner, nay and I bare not a brain.

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.p: Wife, do not vex me, is the bowl gone, is it delivered?

sp.speaker: Mrs.
sp.p: Delivered yes sure,it is delivered.

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.p: I will never more say my prayers, do not make me mad, it is common, let me not cry like a woman, is it gone?

sp.speaker: Mrs.
sp.p: Gone? Good is my witness, I delivered it with no more intention to be cozened on it, than the child new born: and yet

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.p: Look to my house, I am haunted with evil spirits, hear me , do;hear me, if I have not my Goblet again, heaven, I will to the Devil, I will to a Conjurer, look to my house, I will raise all the wise men in the street.

sp.speaker: Mrs.
sp.p: Deliver us what words are these, I trust in God, he is but drunk sure.

sp.speaker: Cocle:
sp.p: I must have the Salmon to worship; Cocledemoy, now for the Master piece, God bless thy neck piece, and Fowtra, Fair Mistress my Master.

sp.speaker: Mrs.
sp.p: Have I caught you, what Roger?

sp.speaker: Cocle:
sp.p: Peace good Mistress, I will tell you all, a Jest,a very mere Jest, your husband only took sport to fright you, the bowl is at my Masters, and there is your husband, who sent me in all haste, lest you should be over frighted with his feigning, to come to dinner to him.

sp.speaker: Mrs.
sp.p: Praise Heaven, it is no worse.

sp.speaker: Cocle:
sp.p: And desired me, to desire you to send the Jowl of Salmon before, and yourself to come after to them, my Mistress would be right glad to see you.

sp.speaker: Mrs.
sp.p: I pray carry it: now thank them entirely: bless me, I was never so out of my skin in my life, pray thank your Mistress most entirely.

sp.speaker: Cocle:
sp.p: So now Figo worshipful Mall Fough, and I will munch Cheaters and Bawds go together like washing and wringing.

sp.speaker: Mrs.
sp.p: Beshrew his heart for his labour, how everything about me quivers, what Christian my hat and apron, here take my sleeves, and how I tremble, so I will gossip it now for it, that is certain, here has been revolutions, and false siers indeed.

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.p: Whether now? What is the matter with you now? whether are you a gadding?

sp.speaker: Mistris.
sp.p: Come, come, play the fool no more: Will you go?

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.p: Whether, in the rank name of madness: whether?

sp.speaker: Mist.
sp.p: Whether, why to master Garnish, to eat the Jowl of Salmon? Lord, how strange you make it?

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.p: Why so, why so.

sp.speaker: Mist.
sp.p: Why so? why did not you send the self-same fellow for the Jowl of Salmon, that had the cup?

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.p: It is well, it is very well.

sp.speaker: Mist.
sp.p: And wild me to come and eat it with you at the Goldsmiths.

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.p: O Aye, aye, aye , art in thy right wits?

sp.speaker: Mist.
sp.p: Do you hear, make a fool of some body else, and you make an ass of me? I will make an Ox of you, do ye see.

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.p: Nay wife be patient, for look you, I may be mad, or drunk, or so, for my own part, though you can bear more than I, yet I can do well: I will not curse nor carry, but heaven knows what I think . Come, let us go hear some music, I will never more say my prayers. Let us go hear some doleful music. Nay if Heaven forget to prosper knaves, I will go no more to the Synagogue. Now I am discontented, I will turn Sectary that is fashion.

div2.stage: Enter Sir Hubert Subboyse, Sir Lyonell Frevile, Crispinella, seruants with lightes.

sp.speaker: Sir Hub.
sp.p: More lights: welcome Sir Lyonell Frevile, brother Frevile shortly. Look to your lights.

sp.speaker: Seruant.
sp.p: The Maskers are at hand.

sp.speaker: Sir Lyo:
sp.p: Call down our daughter: Hark they are at hand, rank handsomely.

div2.stage: Enter the Masquers, they daunce. Enter Maheureus and take Beatrice from Frevile. They draw.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Know sir, I have the advantage of the place.
You are not safe, I would deal even with you.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: So.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: So.

sp.speaker: Bea:
sp.p: I do beseech you sweet, do not for me provoke your Fortune.

sp.speaker: Sir Ly.
sp.p: What sudden flaw is risen?

sp.speaker: Sir Hub.
sp.p: From whence comes this?

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: An ulcer long time lurking, now is burst.

sp.speaker: Sir Hub.
sp.p: Good sir the time and your designs are soft.

sp.speaker: Bea:
sp.p: Aye dear sir, council him, advise him, it will relish well
From your carving: Good my sweet rest safe.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: All is well, all is well, this shall be ended straight.

sp.speaker: Sir Hub.
sp.p: The banquet stays, there we will discourse more large.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Marriage must not make men Cowards.

sp.speaker: Sir Ly.
sp.p: Nor rage fools.

sp.speaker: Sir Hub.
sp.p: It is valour not where heat, but reason rules.

sp.speaker: Tysep.
sp.p: But do you hear Lady, you proud ape you,
What was the Jest you brake of me even now?

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.p: Nothing, I only said you were all mettle, that you had a brazen face, a Leaden brain, and a copper beard.

sp.speaker: Tysep.
sp.p: Quicksilver, thou little more then a Dwarf, and something less than a Woman.

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.p: A Wisp, a wisp, a wisp, will you go to the banquet.

sp.speaker: Tysep.
sp.p: By the Lord I think thou wilt marry shortly too, thou growest somewhat foolish already.

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.p: O I'faith, it is a fair thing to be married, and a necessary, To hear this word, must; if our husbands be proud, we must bear his contempt, if noisome we must bear with the Goat under his armholes, if a fool we must bear his babble, and which is worse, If a loose liver, We must live upon unwholesome Reversions: Where, on the contrary side, our husbands because they may and we must; care not for us, things hoped with fear, and got with strugglings, are men's high pleasures, when duty pales and flats their appetite.

sp.speaker: Tysep.
sp.p: What a tart Monkey is this, by heaven if thou hadst not so much wit I could find in my heart to my marry thee. Faith bear with me for all this.

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.p: Bear with thee, I wonder how thy mother could bear thee ten months in her belly, when I cannot endure thee two hours in mine eye.

sp.speaker: Tysep.
sp.p: Alas for you sweet soul, by the Lord you are grown a proud, scurvy, apish, idle, disdainful, scoffing, Gods foot, because you have read Ephues and his England, Palmerin de Oliva, and the Legend of Lies.

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.p: Why i'faith yet servant, you of all others should bear with my known unmalicious humours, I have always in my Heart given you your due respect:
And heaven my be sworn, I have privately given fair speech of you, and protested.

sp.speaker: Tysep.
sp.p: Nay look you, for my own part, if I have not as religiously vowed my heart to you, been drunk to your health, swallowed flap-dragons, eat glasses, drunk urine, stabbed arms, and done all the offices of protested gallantry for your sake: and yet you tell me I have a brazen face, a leaden brain, and a copper beard, Come yet and it please you.

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.p: No, no, you do not love me?

sp.speaker: Tysep.
sp.p: By ( ) but I do now, and whosoever dares say that I do not love you, nay honour you, and if you would vouchsafe to marry.

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.p: Nay as for that think of it as you will, but God is my record, and my sister knows I have taken drink and slept upon it, that if ever I marry it shall be you, and I will marry, and yet I hope I do not say it shall be you neither.

sp.speaker: Tysep.
sp.p: By heaven I shall be as soon weary of health as of your enjoying: will you cast a smooth cheek upon me?

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.p: I cannot tell, I have no crumped shoulders, my back needs no mantle, and yet marriage is honourable: do you think ye shall prove a Cuckold?

sp.speaker: Tysep.
sp.p: No, by the Lord, not I?

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.p: Why, I thank you i'faith:
Heigh ho: I slept on my back this morning
And dreamt the strangest dreams:
Good Lord, how things will come to pass?
Will you go to the banquet?

sp.speaker: Tysep.
sp.p: If you will be mine, you shall be your own, my purse, my body, my heart is yours, only be silent in my house, modest at my table, and wanton in my bed, and the Empress of Europe cannot content, and shall not be contented better.

sp.speaker: Crisp.
Tysep.
sp.p: Then thus, and thus, so Hymen should begin,
Sometimes a falling out, proves falling in.

div2.stage: Enter Frevile, speaking to some within, Malhereux at the other dore.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: As you respect my virtue, give me leave
To satisfy my reason, though not blood:
So, all runs right, our fained rage hath taken
To fullest life, they are much possessed
Of force most, most all quarrel: now my right friend
Resolve me with open breast, free and true heart
Cannot thy virtue having space to think
and fortify her weakened powers with reason,
Discourses, Meditations, Discipline.
Divine ejaculatories, and all those aids against devils:
Cannot all these curb thy low appetite
and sensual fury?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: "There is no God in blood, no reason in desire:
Shall I but live? Shall I not be forced to act
Some deed, whose very name is hideous?

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: No.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Then I must enjoy Francischina.

sp.speaker: Free.
