sp.l: You shall: I will lend this ring, show it to that fair Devil,
It will resolve me dead, which rumour with my artificial
absence, will make most firm, enjoy her suddenly.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: But if report go strong that you are slain,
and that by me. Whereon I may be seized
Where shall I find your being.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: At master Shatewes the Jewellers,to whose breast
I will trust our secret purpose.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Aye rest yourself, each man hath follies.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: But those worst of all,
"Who with a willing eye, do seeing fall."

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: It is true, but truth seems folly in madness spectacles,
I am not now myself, no man: Farewell.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: Farewell.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: "When woman is in the heart, in the soul hell."

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: Now repentance the fools whip seize thee,
Nay if there be no means I will be thy friend,
But not thy Vices; and with greatest sense
I will force thee feel thy errors, to the worst
The vildest of dangers thou shalt sink into,
No Jeweller shall see me, I will lurk
Where none shall know or think, close I will withdraw,
and leave thee with two friends: a whore and knave
But is this virtue in me? no, not pure,
Nothing extremely best with us endures,
No use in simple purities, the elements
are mixed for use, Silver without allay
Is all too eager to be wrought for use:
Nor precise virtues ever purely good
Holds useful size with temper of weak blood:
Then let my course be born, though: with side wind,
The end being good, the means are well assigned,

div2.stage: Enter Franchischina melancholy, Cockledemoy leading her.

sp.speaker: Cocle:
sp.p: Come catafugo Francke a Franck-hall, who who ho,
Excellent, Ha, here is a plump rumped wench, with a breast
Softer than a Courtiers tongue, an old Ladies gums,
Or an old man's mentula, my fine Rogue.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Pan you poltroon.

sp.speaker: Cocle:
sp.p: Goody fiste, flumpum pumpum, a my fine Wagtail,
Thou art as false as prostituted and adulterate
as some translated manuscript Busse fair whore, busse.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Gods sacrament Pox.

sp.speaker: Cocle:
sp.p: Hadamoy key dost thou frown medianthon teukey
Nay look here: Numeron key Silver blithefor cany
Os cany goblet: Us key ne moyblogefoy oteeston pox
On you Gosling.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: By me faith this been very fine language, I shall bush ye now, ha, be garzon vare had you that plate?

sp.speaker: Cocle:
sp.p: Hedemoy key, get you gone Punk rampant, key common up-tail.

sp.speaker: Mar:
sp.p: O daughter, cozen, niece, servant, mistress.

sp.speaker: Cocle:
sp.p: Humpum, plumpum squat, I am gone.

sp.speaker: Mar:
sp.p: There is one M. Malhereux at the door desires to see you: he says he must not be denied, for he hath sent you this ring and withal says it is done.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: What shall me do now, Gods sacrament: tell him two hours hence he shall be most affectionately welcome, tell him what shall me do) tell him I am been in my bate, and I fall perfume my sweets, make a mine body so delicate for his arm,
Two hours hence.

sp.speaker: Mar:
sp.p: I shall satisfy him two hours hence well.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Now I shall revenge, hey, begar me shall tartar the whole generation, mine brain work it,
Frevile is dead, Malhareux shall hang,
And mine rival Beatrice, I shall make run mad.

sp.speaker: Mar:
sp.p: He is gone forsooth to eat a caudle of Cock-stones, and will return within his two hours.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Very well, give monies to some fellow to squire me, I shall go abroad.

sp.speaker: Mar:
sp.p: There is a lusty Bravo beneath, a stranger, but a good stale Rascal: he swears valiantly, kicks a Bawd right virtuously, and protests with an empty pocket right desperately, He will squire you.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Very welcome, mine fan, I shall return presently, now shall me be revenge ten thousand deula, there shall be no got in me but passion, no thought but rage, no mercy but blood, no spirit but Diula in me,
There shall nothing thought good for me,
But that is mischievous for others.

div2.stage: Enter Sir Hubert, Sir Lyonell, Beatrice, Crispinella, and Nurce. Tissefeu following.

sp.speaker: Sir Ly.
sp.p: Did no one see him since? pray God, nay all is well,
A little heat, what he is but withdrawn? and yet I would to God,
But fear you nothing.

sp.speaker: Bea:
sp.p: Pray God that all be well or would I were not.

sp.speaker: Tysep.
sp.p: He is not to be found Sir any where.

sp.speaker: Sir Ly.
sp.p: You must not make a heavy face presage an ill event: I like your Sister well, she is quick and lively: would she would marry faith.

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.p: Marry, nay and I would marry: methinks an old man is a quiet thing.

sp.speaker: Sir Ly.
sp.p: Ha, mass and so he is.

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.p: You are a Widower.

sp.speaker: Sir L:
sp.p: That I am I'faith fair Crisp. and I can tell you, would you affect me, I have it in me yet I'faith.

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.p: Troth I am in love, let me see your hand: would you cast yourself away upon me willingly?

sp.speaker: Sir Ly.
sp.p: Will I: I by the ( )

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.p: Would you be a Cuckold willingly? By my troth it is a comely, fine, and handsome sight, for one of my years to marry an old man, truth it is restorative, what a comfortable thing it is to think of her husband, to hear his venerable cough a the everlastings, to feel his rough skin, his summer hands, and winter legs, his almost no eyes, and assuredly no teeth, and then to think what she must dream of, when she considers others happiness and her own want: it is a worthy and notorious comfortable match.

sp.speaker: Sir Ly.
sp.p: Pish, pish, will you have me?

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.p: Will you assure me,

sp.speaker: Sir Ly.
sp.p: Five hundred pound jointure.

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.p: That you will die within this fortnight?

sp.speaker: Ly.
sp.p: No, by my faith Cris.

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.p: Then Crisp. by her faith assures you she will have none of you.

div2.stage: Enter Frevile disguis'd like a pandor and Francischina.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Beere leave Gentles and men of nightcaps, I would speak,
But that here stands one is able to express her own tale best.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Sir mine speech is to you, you had a son master Frevile.

sp.speaker: Sir Ly.
sp.p: Had ha, and have.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: No point, me am come to assure you that one mestre Malheureus hath killed him.

sp.speaker: Bea:
sp.p: O me, wretched, wretched.

sp.speaker: Sir Hub.
sp.p: Look to our daughter.

sp.speaker: Sir Ly.
sp.p: How art thou informed?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: If that it please you to go with me, I shall bring you where you shall hear Malheureus with his own lips confess it, and dare ye may apprehend him, and revenge your and mine loves blood.

sp.speaker: Sir Hub.
sp.p: Your loves blood mistress, was he your Love?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: He was so sir, let your daughter hear it: do not weep Lady, the young man that be slain did not love you, for he still loveth me ten thousand thousand times more dearly.

sp.speaker: Bea:
sp.p: O my heart I will love you the better, I cannot hate what he affected? O passion, O my grief which way will break, think and consume?

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.p: Peace.

sp.speaker: Bea:
sp.p: Dear woes cannot speak.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: For look you Lady this your ring he gave me, with most bitter jests at your scorned kindness.

sp.speaker: Bea:
sp.p: He did not ill not to love me, but sure he did not well to mock me: Gentle minds will pity, though they cannot love: yet peace, and my love sleep with him. Unlace good nurce, alas, I was not so ambitious of so supreme an happiness, that he should only love me, it was joy enough for me poor soul that I only might only love him.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: O but to be abused, scorned, scoffed at, O ten thousand diula by such a one, and unto such a one.

sp.speaker: Bea:
sp.p: I think you say not true sister, shall we know one another in the other world?

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.p: What means my sister?

sp.speaker: Bea:
sp.l: I would fain see him again: O my tortured mind,
Frevile is more than dead, he is unkind.

div2.stage: Exit Beat. and Crisp. and Nurse.

sp.speaker: Sir Hub.
sp.l: Convey her in, and so sir as you said
Set a strong watch.

sp.speaker: Sir Ly.
sp.l: Aye sir, and so pass along with this same common woman, you must make it good.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: I shall, or let me pay for his, mine blood.

sp.speaker: Sir Hub.
sp.l: Come then along all, with quiet speed.

sp.speaker: Lion:
sp.l: O Fate?

sp.speaker: Tysep.
sp.l: O sir, be wisely sorry, but not passionate.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: I will go and reveal myself: stay: no, no,
Grief endears Love: Heaven to have such a wife
Is happiness, to breed pale envy in the saints.
Thou worthy Dove-like virgin without gall,
Cannot (that woman's evil) Jealousy,
Despite disgrace, nay which is worst, contempt
Once stir thy faith. O Truth, how few sisters hast thou?
Dear memory, with what a suffering sweetness, quiet modesty,
Yet deep affection she received my death,
And then with what a patient, yet oppressed kindness
She took my lewdly intimated wrongs. O the dearest of heaven?
Were there but three such women in the world, two
Might be saved.
Well, I am great with expectation to what devilish end
This woman of foul soul will drive her plots:
But providence all wicked art over tops.
"And Impudence must know (though stiff as Ice,)
"That fortune doth not always dote on Vice.

div2.stage: Enter sir Hubert, sir Lyonell, Tyssefue, Franch. and three with Halberds.

sp.speaker: Sir Hub.
sp.l: Plant a watch there, be very careful Sirs, the rest with us.

sp.speaker: Tysep.
sp.l: The heavy night grows to her depth of quiet,
It is about amid darkness.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Mine chamber is hard by, I shall bring you to it presantment.

sp.speaker: Sir Ly.
sp.l: Deep silence. On

sp.speaker: Cocle.
sp.p: Wa, ha, ho,

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.p: It was his voice, it is he: he sups with his cupping glasses. It is late, he must pass this way: I will have him, I will have my fine boy, my worshipful Cocledemoy, I will moy him, he shall be hanged in lousy linen, I will hire some sectary to make him an heretic before he die? And when he is dead I will piss on his grave.

sp.speaker: Cocle:
sp.p: Ah my fine punks, good night, Franke, frailty, frail a Frail Hall? Bonus noches my vbiquitari.

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.p: Ware polling and shaving Sir.

sp.speaker: Cocle:
sp.p: A Wolf, a wolf, a wolf,

div2.stage: Exit.Cocledemoy Leauing his cloke behind him.

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.p: Here is something yet, a Cloak, a cloak, yet I will after, he cannot scape the watch, I will hang him if I have any mercy, I will slice him.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Who goes there? come before the Constable.

sp.speaker: Cocle:
sp.p: Bread a God Constable, you are a Watch for the devil, Honest men are robbed under your nose, there is a false knave in the habit of a Vintner, set upon me, he would have had my purse, But I took me to my heels: yet he got my Cloak, a plain stuff cloak poor, yet it will serve to hang him? It is my loss, poor man that I am.

div2.stage: Enter Mulligrub running with Cocledemoys cloke.

sp.p: Masters, we must Watch better, is it not strange that knaves, Drunkards, and thieves, should be abroad , and yet we of the Watch, Scriveners, smiths, and Tailors, never stir.
Hark, who goes there?

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.p: An honest man and a Citizen.
Appear, appear, what are you?

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.p: A simple Vintner.
A Vintner ha, and simple, draw nearer, nearer: here is the Cloak.
I Master Vintner we know you, a plain stuff cloak: it is it.
Right, come: O thou varlet, dost not thou know that the Wicked cannot scape the eyes of the Constable?

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.p: What means this violence, as I am an honest man I took the cloak.
As you are a knave, you took the cloak, we are your witnesses for that.

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.p: But hear me, hear me, I will tell you what I am.
A thief you are.

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.p: I tell you my name is Mullegrub.
I will grub you, In with him to the stocks, there let him sit until tomorrow morning that Justice Quodlibet may examine him.

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.p: Why but I tell thee.
Why but I tell thee, we will tell thee now.

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.p: Am I not mad, am I not an ass,
Why scabs, Gods foot: let me out.
Aye, aye , let him prate, he shall find matter in us scabs I warrant: Gods-so, what good members of the common wealth, do we prove.
Prithee peace, let us remember our duties, and let go sleep, in the fear of God.

div2.stage: Hauing left Mullegrub in the stocks.

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.p: Who goes there: Illo, ho, ho: 'swounds shall I run mad,
Lose my wits: shall I be hanged, hark: who goes there? Do not
fear to be poor Mullegrub,
Thou hast a sure stock now.

sp.speaker: Cocle:
sp.l: The night grows old,
And many a cuckold is now Wha, ha, ha, ho,
Maids on their backs,
Dream of sweet smacks, and warm: Wo, ho, ho, ho,
sp.p: I must go comfort my venerable Mullegrub, I must
Fiddle him till he fyst: fough:
sp.l: Maids in your Night-rails,
Look well to your light (---)
Keep close your locks,
and down your smocks,
Keep a broad eye
And a close thigh,
sp.p: excellent, excellent, who is there?
Now Lord, Lord, (master Mullegrub) deliver us:what does your Worship in the stocks? I pray come out Sir.

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.p: 'swounds man I tell thee I am locked.

sp.speaker: Cocle:
sp.p: Locked: O world: O men: O time: o night: that canst not
Discern virtue, and wisdom, and one of the common Counsel: What is your Worship in for?

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.p: For a plague (of it) suspicion of Felony.

sp.speaker: Cocle:
sp.p: Nay, and it be but such a trifle, Lord I could weep, to see your good Worship in this taking: your Worship has been a good friend to me, and though you have forgot me, yet I knew your wife before she was married, and since I have found your Worships. door open and I have knocked, and God knows what I have saved: and do I live to see your Worship stocked?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Honest Belman, I perceive thou knowest me, I prithee call the Watch. Inform the Constable of my reputation,
That I may no longer abide in this shameful habitation,
And hold thee, all I have about me.

sp.speaker: Cocle:
sp.p: It is more than I deserve sir: Let me alone for your Delivery.

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.p: Do, and then let me alone with Cockledemoy, I will moy him.

sp.speaker: Cocle:
sp.p: Maids in your: Master Constable, whose that in the stocks?
One for a robbery: one Mullegrub, he calls himself. Mullegrub? Bellman, knowest thou him?

sp.speaker: Cocle:
sp.p: Know him: O master Constable what good service have you done. Know him? He is a strong thief, his house has been suspected for a bawdy Tavern a great while: and a receipt for Cut-purses, it is most certain: He has been long in the black book, and is he taken now?
Byrlady my masters we will not trust the stocks with him, We will have him to the Justices, get a Mittimus to Newgate presently. Come sir, come on sir.

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.p: Ha: does your Rascalship yet know my Worship In the end?
Aye , the end of your Worship we know.

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.p: Ha, goodman Constable, here is an honest fellow can tell you what I am?
It is true sir, you are a strong thief he says on his own knowledge: Bind fast, bind fast, we know you: We will trust no Stocks with you. Away with him to the Jail instantly.

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.p: Why but dost hear Bellman, Rogue, Rascal, Gods
Why but?

sp.speaker: Cocle:
sp.p: Why but; wha ha ha, excellent, excellent, ha my fine Cocledemoy, my Vintner fistes, I will make him fart crackers before I have done with him; tomorrow is the day of Judgment.
Afore the Lord God my knavery grows unparegal,
It is time to take a nap, until half an hour hence:
God give your Worship Music, content, and rest.

div2.stage: Enter Franchischina, sir Lyonel, Tissefeu, with Officers.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: You been very welcome to mine chamber.

sp.speaker: Lyo.
sp.l: But how know ye, how are ye assured
Both of the deed, and of his sure return.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: O Mine here. I shall tell you, metre Malhereux
Came all breathless running a my chamber
His sword all bloody: he tell a me he had kill Frevile,
And prayed a me to conceal him:
I flatter him, bid bring monies, he should live and lie with me,
He went whilst I (me hope without sins) out of mine
Mush love to Frevile betray him.

sp.speaker: Sir Lyo.
sp.l: Fear not, it is well: good works get grace for sin.

div2.stage: She conceales them behinde the curtaine.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Dear, peace, rest dear, so softly, all go in:
The net is lay, now shall I be revenge.
If that me knew a dog that Frevile love,
Me would poison him, for know the deepest hell
As a revenging Woman's, naught so fell.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.l: Ho Cousin Francke, the party you wot of, M. Malhereux.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Bid him come up, I prayed.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: O min here man, a dear liver Love,
Mine ten thousand times welcome Love,
Ha, by mine trat, you been the just, what shall me say :
What sweet honey name shall I call you?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Any from you is pleasure. Come my loving Prettinesse, where is thy Chamber?
I long to touch your sheets.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: No, no, not yet mine sweetest soft lipped love:
You shall not gulp down all delights at once:
Be mine trat, this all-fleas-lovers, this ravenous Wenches
That sallow all down hole, will have all at one bit,
Fie, fie, fie, be mine faith they do cate
Comfits with spoons.
No, no, I will make you chew your pleasure with love,
"The more degrees and steps, the more delight,
"The more endeared is the pleasure hight.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: What your a learned wanton, and proceed by art?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Go little wag, pleasure should have a
Cranes long neck, to relish the Ambrosia of Delight.
And I prethee tell me, for me loves to hear of manhood
Very mush, Isait: I prayed (what was me a-saying)
O, I prayed tell a me:
How did you kill a metre Frevile?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Why quarrelled a set purpose, drew him out,
Singled him, and having the advantage of my sword and might, ran him through and through.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: What did you with him when he was stuck?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: I dragged him by the heels to the next wharf and spurned him in the River.

div2.stage: Those in ambush rusheth forth and takes him.

sp.speaker: sir Lyo.
sp.l: Seize, seize him: O monstrous? O ruthless Villain?

sp.speaker: Mul.
sp.l: What mean you Gentlemen? by heaven,

sp.speaker: Tysep.
sp.l: Speak not of anything that is good.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Your errors gives you passion: Frevile lives.

sp.speaker: Sir Lyo.
sp.l: Thy own lips say, thou liest.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Let me die if at Shatewes the Jeweller, he lives not safe untouched.

sp.speaker: Tysep.
sp.l: Mean time to strictest guard, to sharpest prison.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: No rudeness Gentlemen: I will go undragged.
O wicked, wicked Devil.

sp.speaker: Sir Lyo.
sp.l: Sir, the day of trial is this morn,
Let us prosecute the sharpest rigour, and severest end:
"Good men are cruel, when they are vices friend.

sp.speaker: Sir Hub.
sp.l: Woman we thank thee, with no empty hand,
Strumpets are fit, fit for something.
Farewell.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: I, for Hell: O thou unreprievable, beyond all
Measure of Grace damned immediately:
That things of beauty created for sweet use:
Soft comfort, and as the very music of life,
Custom should make so unutterably hellish?
O heaven: what difference is in women, and their life?
What man, but worthy name of Man:
Would leave the modest pleasures of a lawful bed:
The holy union of two equal hearts
Mutually holding either dear as health,
The undoubted issues, Joys of chaste sheets,
The unfeigned embrace of sober Ignorance:
To twine the unhealthful loins of common Loves,
The prostituted impudence of things.
Senseless like those by Cataracts of Nile,
"Their use so vile, takes away sense how vile,"
"To love a creature, made of blood and hell,"
"Whose use makes weak, whole company doth shame,"
"Whose bed doth beggar: issue doth defame."

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Metre Frevile live: ha, ha, live at mestre Shatewes:
Mush at metre Shatews. Frevile is dead. Malhereux shall hang,
And sweet devil, that Beatrice would but run mad, that
she would but run mad, then me would dance and sing,
Metre Don Dubon, me pre ye now go to Mestres
Beatrice, tell her Frevile is sure dead, and that he
Curse herself especially, for that he was
Sticked in her quarrel, swearing in his last gasp,
That if it had been in mine quarrels,
It would never have grieved him.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: I will.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Prayed do, and say anything that will vex her.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Let me alone to vex her.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Will you, will you make a her run mad? here take
This ring, see me scorn to wear anything that was hers,
Or his: I prayed torment her, I cannot love her,
She honest and virtuous forsooth.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Is she so? O vile creature? then let me alone with her.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: What. Will you make a her mad? sweet by mine trat,
Be pretta servant, Bush, I shall go to bet now.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: Mischief whether wilt thou? O thou tear-less woman?
How monstrous is thy Devil,
The end of Hell as thee.
How miserable were it to be virtuous, if thou couldst prosper?
I will to my Love, the faithful Beatrice,
She has wept enough, and faith dear soul too much.
But yet how sweet it is to think
How dear ones life was to his Love: how mourned his death.
It is Joy not to be expressed with breath:
But O let him that would such passion drink,
Be quiet of his speech, and only think .

sp.speaker: Bet.
sp.p: Sister, cannot a woman kill herself? Is it not lawful to die when we should not live?

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.p: O sister it is a question not for us, we must do what God will.

sp.speaker: Bea:
sp.p: What God will? Alas, can torment be his glory, or our grief his pleasure? Does not the Nurses nipple juiced over with Wormwood, bid the child it should not suck? And does not Heaven when it hath made our breath bitter unto us, say we should not live? O my best sister: to suffer wounds when one may scape this rod, is against nature, that is against God.

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.p: Good sister do not make me weep: sure Frevile was not false:
sp.l: I will gage my life that strumpet out of craft
And some close second end hath maliced him.

sp.speaker: Bea:
sp.l: O sister if he were not false, whom have I lost?
If he were: what grief to such unkindness,
From head to foot I am all misery:
Only in this, some justice I have found
My grief is like my love, beyond all bound.

sp.speaker: Nurse.
sp.p: My servant, master Cacature desires to visit you,

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.p: For griefs sake keep him out, his discourse is like the
long word, Honorificabilitudinitatibus: a great deal
Of sound and no sense: his company is like a parenthesis,
To a discourse you may admit it, or leave it out, it makes no matter.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: By your leave sweet creatures.

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.p: Sir, all I can yet say of you, is, you are uncivil.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: You must deny it: By your sorrows leave,
I bring some music, to make sweet your grief,

sp.speaker: Bea:
sp.l: What ere you please: O break my heart
Canst thou yet pant? O dost thou yet survive,
Thou didst not love him, if thou now canst live:
O Love, how strangely sweet
are thy weak Passions,
That love and joy should meet
in self same fashions.
O who can tell
the cause why this should move?
But only this,
no reason,ask of Love.

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.l: Hold, peace, the gentlest soul is swooned, O my best sister,

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Ha, get you gone, close the doors: My Beatrice,

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Cursed be my indiscreet trials: O my immeasurably loving .

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.l: She stirs, give air, she breathes.

sp.speaker: Bea:
sp.l: Where am I, ha? how have I slipped off life?
Am I in heaven? O my Lord, though not loving
By our eternal being, yet give me leave
To rest by thy dear side: am I not in heaven?

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: O eternally much loved, recollect your spirits.

sp.speaker: Bea:
sp.l: Ha, you do speak, I do see you, I do live,
I would not die now: Let me not burst with wonder.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: Call up your blood, I live to honour you,
As the admired glory of your sex.
Nor ever hath my love been false to you,
Only I presumed to try your faith too much,
For which I most am grieved.

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.l: Brother, I must be plain with you, you have wronged us.
I am not so Covetous to deny it,
But yet when my discourse hath stayed your quaking,
You will be smoother lipped: and the delight
And satisfaction which we all have got,
Under these strange disguisings, when you know,
You will be mild and quiet, forget at last,
"It is much joy to think on sorrows past."

sp.speaker: Bea:
sp.l: Do you then live? and are you not untrue?
Let me not die with Joy, pleasure is more extreme
Than grief, there is nothing sweet to man but mean.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Heaven cannot be too gracious to such goodness, I shall discourse to you the several chances, but hark I must yet rest disguised, the sudden close of many drifts now meet,
sp.l: "Where pleasure hath some profit,art is sweet.

sp.speaker: Tysep.
sp.p: News, news, news, news.

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.p: Oysters, Oysters, oysters, oysters.

sp.speaker: Tysep.
sp.p: Why, is not this well now? Is not this better then louring, and pouting, and puling, which is hateful to the living, and vain to the dead? Come, come, you must live by the quick, when all is done, and for my own part, let my wife laugh at me when I am dead, so she will smile upon me whilst I live, but to see a woman Whine, and yet keep her eyes dry: mourn, and yet keep her cheeks fat: nay, to see a woman claw her husband by the feet when he is dead, that would have scratched him by the face when he was living: this now is somewhat ridiculous.

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.p: Lord how you prate.

sp.speaker: Tysep.
sp.p: And yet I was afraid i'faith that I should have seen a Garland on this beauties hearse, but time, truth, experience, and variety, are great doers with women.

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.p: But what is the news? the news I pray you?

sp.speaker: Tysep.
sp.p: I pray you? never pray me: for by your leave you may command me. This it is:
sp.l: the public sessions which this day is past, hath doomed to death ill fortuned Malhereux.

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.l: But sir, we heard he offered to make good,
That Freuile lived at Shatews the Jewellers.

sp.speaker: Bea:
sp.l: And that it was but a plot betwixt them two.

sp.speaker: Tysep.
sp.l: O Aye, aye , he gaged his life with it, but know
When all approached the test, Shatews denied
He saw or heard of any such complot,
Or of Freuill: so that his own defence,
Appeared so false, that like a madman's sword,
He stroke his own heart, he hath the course of law
and instantly must suffer: but the Jest
(If hanging be a jest) as many make it)
Is to take notice of one Mullegrub, a sharking vintner.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: What of him Sir.

sp.speaker: Tysep.
sp.p: Nothing but hanging, the Whoreson slave is mad before he hath lost his senses.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: Was his fact clear and made apparent Sir?

sp.speaker: Tysep.
sp.l: No faith suspicions, for it was thus protested
a cloak was stolen, that cloak he had, he had it
Himself confessed by force, the rest of his defence
The choler of a Justice wronged in wine,
Joined with malignance of some hasty Jurors,
Whose wit was lighted by the Justice nose, The knave was cast,
But Lord to hear his moan, his prayers, his wishes,
His zeal ill timed, and his words unpitied,
Would make a dead man rise and smile,
Whilst he observed how fear can make men vile.

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.l: Shall we go meet the execution?

sp.speaker: Bea:
sp.l: I shall be ruled by you.

sp.speaker: Tysep.
sp.l: By my troth a rare motion, you must haste ,
For male-factors goes like the world upon wheels.

sp.speaker: Bea:
sp.l: Will you man us, you shall be our guide to Freuile.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: I am your servant.

sp.speaker: Tysep.
sp.l: Ha servant? 'swounds I am no companion for Panders, your best make him your love.

sp.speaker: Bea:
sp.l: So will I Sir, we must live by the quick you say.

sp.speaker: Tysep.
sp.l: Sdeath a virtue, what a damned thing is this?
Whole trust fair faces, tears, and vows, Sdeath not I,
She is a woman, that is, she can lie.

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.l: Come, come, turn not a man of time, to make all ill,
Whose goodness you conceive not, since the worst of chance
Is to crave grace for heedless ignorance.

sp.speaker: Cocle:
sp.p: So, I have lost my Sergeant in an ecliptic mist, drunk, horrible drunk, he is fine: so now will I fit myself, I hope this habit will do me no harm, I am an honest man already: fit, fit, fit as a punks tail, that serves everybody: By this time my Vintner thinks of nothing but hell and sulphur, he farts fire and brimstone already, hang toasts, the execution approacheth.

div2.stage: Enter Sir Lyonell: Sir Hubert, Malhereux piniond, Tysefeu, Beatrice, Frevile, Crisp. Francischina, and Holberds.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: I do not blush, although condemned by laws,
No kind of death is shameful but the cause:
Which I do know is none, and yet my lust
Hath made the one (although not cause) most just.
May I not be reprieved? Freuile is but mislodged,
Some lethargy hath seized him, no, much malice,
Do not lay blood upon your souls with good intents,
Men may do ill and law sometime repents.

div2.stage: Cockledemoy picks Malhereuxes pocket of his purse.

sp.speaker: Sir Lyo.
sp.l: Sir, sir, prepare, vain is all lewd defence.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: "Conscience was law: but now laws Conscience,"
My endless peace is made, and to the poor,
My purse, my purse.

sp.speaker: Cocle:
sp.p: I Sir, and it shall please you the poor has your purse already.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: You are a Welyman,
But now thou source of Devils, O how I loathe
The very memory of that I adored,
He that is of fair blood, well meaned, of good breeding,
Best famed, of sweet acquaintance and true friends,
And would with desperate Impudence lose all these,
And hazard landing at this fatal shore,
Let him never kill, nor steal, but love a Whore.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: The man does rave, think a got, think a got, and bid the flesh, the world, and the dibble farewell.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Farewell.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Farewell.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: What is it you say, ha?

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: Sir your pardon, with my this defence,
Do not forget protested violence
Of your low affections no requests,
No arguments of reason, no known danger.
No assured wicked bloodiness,
Could draw your heart from this damnation.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Why stay.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Unprosperous Devil, what shall me do now.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: Therefore to force you from the truer danger,
I wrought the fained, suffering this fair Devil,
In shape of woman to make good her plot,
And knowing that the hook was deeply fast,
I gave her line at will, till with her own vain strivings,
See here she is tired: O thou comely damnation?
Dost think that vice is not to be withstood,
O what is woman merely made of blood.

sp.speaker: Sir Ly.
sp.p: You maze us all, let us not be lost in darkness?

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: All shall be lighted, but this time and place
Forbids longer speech, only what you can think
Has been extremely ill, is only hers.

sp.speaker: Sir Ly.
sp.l: To severest prison with her, with what heart canst live?
What eyes behold a face?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: I will not speak, torture, torture your fill,
For me am worse than hanged, me have lost my will.

sp.speaker: Sir Ly.
sp.l: To the extremest whip and Jail.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: Frolic, how is it Sirs?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: I am myself, how long wast ere I could
Persuade my passion to grow calm to you?
Rich sense makes good bad language, and a friend
Should weigh no action, but the actions end.
I am now worthy yours, when before
The beast of man, loose blood distempered us,
"He that lust rules cannot be virtuous."

div2.stage: Enter Mullegrub mistris Mullegrub and officers.

sp.speaker: Offi.
sp.p: On a fore there, room for the prisoners?

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.p: I pray you do not lead me to execution through cheapside, I owe M.Burnish the gold smith money, and I fear he will set a Sergeant on my back for it.

sp.speaker: Cocle:
sp.p: Trouble not your sconce my Christian Brothers, but have an eye unto the main chance, I will warrant your shoulders, as for your neck Plinius secundus, or marcus Tullius Cycero, or somebody it is says, that a three-fold cord is hardly broken.

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.p: Well, I am not the first honest man that hath been cast away, and I hope shall not be the last.

sp.speaker: Cocle:
sp.p: O sir, have a good stomach and maws, you shall have a joyful supper.

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.p: In troth I have no stomach to it, and it please you take my trencher I use to fast at nights.

sp.speaker: mistris mul.
sp.p: O husband, I little thought you should have come to think on God thus soon: nay and you had been hanged deservedly, it would never have grieved me, I have known of many honest innocent men have been hanged deservedly, but to be cast away for nothing.

sp.speaker: Cocle:
sp.p: Good woman hold your peace, your prattles and your prattles your bibbles and your babbles, for I pray you hear me in private, I am a widower, and you are almost a widow, shall I be welcome to your houses, to your tables, and your other things.

sp.speaker: mist mul.
sp.p: I have a piece of mutton and a feather bed for you at all times, I pray make haste .

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.p: I do here make my confession, if I owe any man anything, I do heartily forgive him: if any man owe me anything, let him pay my wife.

sp.speaker: Cocle:
sp.p: I will look to your wives payment I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.p: And now good yoke-fellow leave thy poor mulligrub.

sp.speaker: mist. mul.
sp.p: Nay then I were unkind i'faith, I will not leave you until I have seen you hang.

sp.speaker: Cocle:
sp.p: But brothers, brothers, you must think of your sins and iniquities, you have been a broacher of profane vessels, you have made us drink of the juice of the whore of Babylon, for whereas good ale, Peeys, Bragets, Ciders, and metheglins, was the true ancient British and Trojan drinks, you have brought in Popish wines, Spanish wines, French wines, tam marti quam merurio, both muscadine and malmsey, to the subversion, staggering, and sometimes overthrow of many a good Christian: You have been a great Jumbler, O remember the sins of your nights, for your night works have been unsavoury in the taste of your Customers.

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.p: I confess I confess, and I forgive as I would be forgive, Do you know one Cocledemoy?

sp.speaker: Cocle:
sp.p: O very well; know him? an honest man he is and a comely, an upright dealer with his neighbours, and their wives speak good things of him.

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.p: Well, wheresoever he is, or whatsoever he is, I will take it on my death he is the cause of my hanging, I heartily forgive him, and if he would come forth he might save me, for he only knows the why, and the wherefore.

sp.speaker: Cocle:
sp.p: You do from your hearts, and midriss, and entrails forgive him then, you will not let him rot in rusty Irons, procure him to be hanged in lousy linen without a song, and after he is dead piss on his grave.

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.p: That hard heart of mine has procured all this, but I forgive as I would be forgiven.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Hang toasts my Worships.

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.p: behold thy Cocledemoy, my fine vintner, my castrophomicall fine boy: behold and see.

sp.speaker: Tysep.
sp.p: Bliss, a the blessed, who would but look for 2. knaves here?

sp.speaker: Cocle:
sp.p: No knave worships. friend, no knave, for observe honest Cocledemoy restores whatsoever he has got, to make you know, that whatsoever he has done, has been only Euphonia gratia, for Wits sake: I acquit this Vintner as he has acquitted me, all has been done for Emphasis of wit my fine boy, my worshipful friends.

sp.speaker: Tysep.
sp.p: Go you are a flattering knave.

sp.speaker: Cocle:
sp.p: I am so, it is a good thriving trade, it comes forward better than the seven liberal Sciences, or the nine cardinal virtues, which may well appear in this, you shall never have flattering knave turn courtier: and yet I have read of many Courtiers that have turned flattering knaves.

sp.speaker: Sir Hub.
sp.p: Was it even but so, why then all is well?

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.p: I could even weep for joy.

sp.speaker: mist mul.
sp.p: I could weep too, but God knows for what.

sp.speaker: Tysep.
sp.p: Hers another tack to be given, your son and daughter.

sp.speaker: Sir Hub.
sp.p: Is it possible, heart I, all my heart, will you be joined here?

sp.speaker: Tysep.
sp.p: yes faith father, marriage and hanging are spun both in one hour .

sp.speaker: Cocle:
sp.p: Why then my worships. good friends I bid myself most heartily welcome to your merry nuptials, and wanton Iiagga-ioggies And now my very fine Heliconian Gallants, and you my Worships. friends in the middle Region:
sp.l: If with content our hurtless mirth hath been,
Let your pleased minds as our much care hath been:
For he shall find that slights such trivial wit,
It is easier to reprove than better it:
We scorn to fear, and yet we fear to swell,
We do not hope it is best: it is all, if Well.
